 title : The django-foaf Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The purpose of this module is to free user&#39;s social graph by the use of the foaf format. A user creates his profile in the editor, including relations, or directly imports his foaf file. The generated user profile will be available from the web as a foaf file. User&#39;s profiles are not locked anymore in a closed datastore but remains free and under user&#39;s control. </p>

<p>The version 0.1 is still a beta. </p>

<p>FeaturesGeneric foaf viewer: can view any foaf file from an url Builtin foaf editor Import of foaf files Relationship management Discovery browsing through relations DependenciesRdflib: http://rdflib.net/ RdfAlchemy: http://www.openvest.com/trac/wiki/RDFAlchemy InstallThis software works with django 0.97 svn </p>

<p>Put the folder django_foaf in your python path Copy and adapt the templates in your project Copy the content of the templatetags folder in one of your registered app templatetags folder Add this line to your urls.py: 
<br/> (r&#39;^foaf/&#39;, include(&#39;django_foaf.urls&#39;)),Add these lines to settings:  FOAF_DATA=&#39;/var/www/mysite/rdf/foaf/&#39;
<br/> FOAF_URI=&#39;http://www.mysite.org/rdf/foaf/&#39;
<br/> FOAF_MAX_LINES=1200FOAF_DATA is the local path where you want to store the user&#39;s foaf files. This directory must be accessible to your web server. FOAF_URI is the external uri from where the user&#39;s foaf files will be accessible from the web. FOAF_MAX_LINES is the maximum of lines a foaf file can have to be parsed. This can be used to preserve the ressources of your system. Notes </p>

<p>This module does not use the database, all the data is stored and processed in rdf files. </p>

<p>The application is not yet internationalized: all the application messages are in french. Help welcome. </p>

<p>UsePlease report any bugs </p>

<p>Contribute and feedbackFeel free to improve the code or to come talk about the module: syntax_error in #django-fr on irc.freenode.net - Site: http://www.patrainet.com</p>

 title : The django-friendfeed Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django-frontendadmindjango-frontendadmin is a set of templatetags to allow an easy and unobstrusive way to edit model-data in the frontend of your page. </p>

<p>Primary repository: http://github.com/bartTC/django-frontendadmin/ </p>

<p>Quick installation instruction
<br/>==============================</p>

<p>1. Put ``frontendadmin`` in your ``INSTALLED_APPS`` in the settings.py of your
<br/>   django project.</p>

<p>2. Add ``django.core.context_processors.request`` to your ``TEMPLATE_CONTEXT_PROCESSORS``
<br/>   in the settings.py of your django project. If this is not available (default since
<br/>   some days) put this snippet into your settings::</p>

<p>    TEMPLATE_CONTEXT_PROCESSORS = (
<br/>        &#39;django.core.context_processors.request&#39;,
<br/>        &#39;django.core.context_processors.auth&#39;,
<br/>        &#39;django.core.context_processors.debug&#39;,
<br/>        &#39;django.core.context_processors.i18n&#39;,
<br/>        &#39;django.core.context_processors.media&#39;,
<br/>    )</p>

<p>3. Include frontendadmin urls in your urlsconf::</p>

<p>    (r&#39;^frontendadmin/&#39;, include(&#39;frontendadmin.urls&#39;)),</p>

<p>4. Load the ``frontendadmin_tags`` library in every template you want to use
<br/>   the frontendamin links. (see below)::</p>

<p>    {% load frontendadmin_tags %}</p>

<p>5. There are three templatetags to either create, change or delete objects::</p>

<p>    {% frontendadmin_add queryset_of_objects %}
<br/>    {% frontendadmin_change object_to_change %}
<br/>    {% frontendadmin_delete object_to_delete %}</p>

<p>   Assumed that you have a weblog application and using generic-views, your
<br/>   template might look so::</p>

<p>    {% for entry in object_list %}
<br/>    
<br/>      {{ entry.title }}
<br/>      {{ entry.body }}
<br/>    
<br/>    {% endfor %}</p>

<p>   A proper implementation of frontendadmin would be::</p>

<p>    {% frontendadmin_add object_list %}
<br/>    {% for entry in object_list %}
<br/>    
<br/>      {{ entry.title }}
<br/>      {{ entry.body }}
<br/>      {% frontendadmin_change entry %}
<br/>      {% frontendadmin_delete entry %}
<br/>    
<br/>    {% endfor %}</p>

<p>6. Thats all. Frontendadmin will automatically check whether the current user has
<br/>   add/change/delete permissions for the given model.</p>

<p>   Frontendadmin has build-in ajax support using the jquery library. See the
<br/>   template-sources for details.</p>

<p>License
<br/>=======</p>

<p>The application is licensed under the ``New BSD License``. See the LICENSE File
<br/>for details.</p>

 title : The django-gateway Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A simple traditional web service (1)receives a request, (2)authenticates the requesting client, then (3)deserializes the parameters, (4)executes the service (the whole point of it)  then (5)serializes the result and (6)returns it to the client. Django-Gateway lets you focus in writing the code and handles the rest. </p>

<p>1. DG recives POST or GET requests through configurable dynamic urls (all using django&#39;s url features). </p>

<p>2. DG uses integrates with the django auth module by limitig access to certain specified groups. </p>

<p>3. DG currently supports serializing with simplejson but it should be easy to extend its capabilities to support xml, amf, and others just by implementing a serialize and deserialize method extending the Service class. </p>

<p>4. DG uses decorators to specify public methods and authentication parameters. A simple yet functional service class looks like this: </p>

<p>class foo(JsonService): </p>

<p>@ServiceMethod 
<br/>def bar(self,p): 
<br/>&quot;&quot;&quot;FooBar plus parameter.&quot;&quot; 
<br/>return &quot;FooBar &quot;+p</p>

A lot of design decisions need to be made so what is there isn&#39;t set in stone (I need to figure out the best way to interface with GitPython). </p>

 title : The django-interval-field Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Field for saving data like timetables.  </p>

<p>models.py: </p>

<p># -*- coding: utf-8 -*-</p>

<p>from django.db import models</p>

<p>from fields import IntervalField</p>

<p>class IntervalTest(models.Model):
<br/>    i = IntervalField()views.py: </p>

<p>obj = IntervalTest.objects.get()</p>

<p>obj.interval_i[8:12] = &#39;Jack&#39;
<br/>obj.interval_i[12:20] = &#39;John&#39;</p>

<p>...</p>

<p>obj.interval_i[5] == &#39;Jack&#39;
<br/>obj.interval_i[15] == &#39;John&#39;You can also use datetime() as a key. </p>

<p>Based on IntervalMap code.</p>

 title : The django-licenses Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>With django-licenses you can give every object a different content license. You can easily manage your licenses and use them in other ways too. Check out some examples on how to use django-licenses.</p>
 summary : <p>July 12, 2009: In the next few days I will be checking in a backwards-incompatible change that will convert django-locationtracking into a GeoDjango app. The benefits it will be bringing include things like location awareness (it can find which (defined) position you&#39;re nearest - i.e. if you create an &quot;Office&quot; item with a lat/lon it can show only a named position if you like/prefer.) and just being cool. Please use a svn rev. of 19 or before if you will not be using a spatial database and have a working GeoDjango environment set up. </p>

<p>This app is built for those who desire (and understand the privacy implications) to add location tracking to their tumblelogs/sites.  It is being extracted from a private site, and is capable of talking to instamapper.com (who have a decent iPhone app and Java apps for many other phones), APRS over amateur radio, the SPOT satellite tracking service, and (non-live) output files from hardware GPS loggers. </p>

<p>A demo screencast is available at http://www.adamfast.com/programming/locationtracking/ </p>

<p>The intro lightning talk video from DjangoCon 2008 is available at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=61u9Y5Zi0_w&amp;feature=PlayList&amp;p=D415FAF806EC47A1&amp;index=6 and begins at 14:51.</p>

 title : The django-markdown2 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is a simple app, which supplies a single template tag for markdown markup. </p>

<p>Dependenciesdjango-markdown2 depends on python-markdown2, which can be found at http://code.google.com/p/python-markdown2. </p>

<p>SourcesPlease note, that this is not main repository. Active development is in the GIT. Download latest sources from http://github.com/svetlyak40wt/django-markdown2: </p>

<p>git clone git://github.com/svetlyak40wt/django-markdown2.git </p>

<p>Installation and usage Place django_markdown2 somewhere in your PYTHONPATH.  Add django_markdown2 to you INSTALLED_APPS.  In any template do: </p>

<p>        {% load md2 %}
<br/>        {{ variable|markdown }} Or specify additional extensions: </p>

<p>        {% load md2 %}
<br/>        {{ variable|markdown:&quot;safe, code-friendly, code-color&quot; }}</p>
 summary : <p>Django-MarkupsNotice: Project is in alpha stage! This currently doesn&#39;t include actual markdowns at all, only framework where adding markup functions is easy. I&#39;m just starting to include them. </p>

<p>Warning: I might refactor the code significantly at this point of development. </p>

<p>Allows easier way to do models that uses markup, using custom field called MarkupField. </p>

<p>This field is actually ForeignKey but using custom widgets and fields it provides more user friendly interface. Behind the scenes all markups are saved to Markup model, which contains markup, content, content_render fields behind the scenes. </p>

<p>UI allows users to choose the markup they wish to use, and write using it directly to textarea. I&#39;m planning to add the customizations using JS and CSS to the specific markup choices and textareas. </p>

<p>Usageclass MyModel(models.Model):
<br/>    description = MarkupField()
<br/>    ...More detailed use case can be seen in svn at trunk/examples/dmarkupsexample/ which contains django project. </p>

<p>DependenciesCurrently there are no actual dependencies, besides that this requires django to be in python path. Django must include the newforms merge, for instance I have tried with Django 1.0. </p>

<p>DevelopmentSVN trunk/ is the development root and same time Eclipse PyDev project called django-markups, and thus should be checked out named as django-markups. If you wish to use PyDev project, the files has dependency to project called django which is the Django itself. So you need to checkout django to your Eclipse workspace too, this in fact is very handy since it provides full auto completion of django libraries too.</p>

 title : The django-minlis Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>MinLis, or Minute Listener, runs saved events at a scheduled time. It works as a background thread that wakes up every 60 seconds. It checks the database for any events scheduled to run, fires those events, and goes back to sleep. The events are django models saved to the database. They store the scheduled time to run and how often to repeat (if at all). So far there are two type of events, events that can run a method on a model (using generics) and events that run a string through python&#39;s eval(). This way, to schedule something to run, all you have to do is save an Event to the database. </p>

<p>Scheduling a background task is as easy as saving a model! </p>

<p>I&#39;m currently doing some more bug testing and polishing things, but when I&#39;m done I will put up the code for all to work on. </p>

<p>Please contact me if you would like the code or more information.</p>
 title : The django-mobilejp Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django-mobilejp is a plugin to build a mobile web site with Django rapidly. As you can guess from its name, it&#39;s intended to be used solely for mobile sites in Japan.</p>
 summary : <p>SummaryProvides row-level versioning of models.  Single function call generates a shadow model and adds the following attributes to the base model: </p>

<p>&#39;&#39;&#39;versions&#39;&#39;&#39; - a QuerySet of all versions of the current instance &#39;&#39;&#39;revert(revision_num)&#39;&#39;&#39; - reverts the instance back to the specified version.  If revision_num is negative, reverts back that many steps Also provides an undelete() utility that, given a model class and instance id, will undelete an instance based on it&#39;s last stored version. </p>

<p>OrganizationAll application logic is in init.py.  tests.py contains the doctest and dummy models used by it. </p>

<p>See the doctest in tests.py for useage examples. </p>

<p>Installation:copy/symlink the modelversions folder into your project folder add modelversions to your INSTALLED_APPS in settings.py as usual following a model defininition in models.py call version_model().  Pass in the base model and assign the result to a local variable. re-sync your app to generate the version tables Warning: this code is under active development and is provided without warranty.</p>

 title : The django-multidb Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The django-multilingual-model Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Provides support for multilingual fields. </p>

<p>The goal of this project is to Keep It Simple (Stupid!) ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keep_it_simple_stupid ) so there is only 33lines of code (excluding the comments). </p>

<p>     Example: </p>

<p>models.py </p>

<p>    from django.db import models
<br/>    from multiling import MultilingualModel
<br/>    
<br/>    class Language(models.Model):
<br/>        code = models.CharField(max_length=5)
<br/>        name = models.CharField(max_length=16)
<br/>        
<br/>    class BookTranslation(models.Model):
<br/>        language = models.ForeignKey(&quot;Language&quot;)
<br/>        title = models.CharField(max_length=32)
<br/>        description = models.TextField()
<br/>        model = models.ForeignKey(&quot;Book&quot;)
<br/>        
<br/>    class Book(MultilingualModel):
<br/>        ISBN = models.IntegerField()
<br/>        
<br/>        class Meta:
<br/>            translation = BookTranslation
<br/>            multilingual = [&#39;title&#39;, &#39;description&#39;]&gt;&gt;&gt; lang_en = Language(code=&quot;en&quot;, name=&quot;English&quot;)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; lang_en.save()
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; lang_pl = Language(code=&quot;pl&quot;, name=&quot;Polish&quot;)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; book = Book(ISBN=&quot;1234567890&quot;)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; book.save()
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; book_en = BookTranslation()
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; book_en.title = &quot;Django for Dummies&quot;
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; book_en.description = &quot;Django described in simple words.&quot;
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; book_en.model = book
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; book_en.save()
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; book_pl = BookTranslation()
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; book_pl.title = &quot;Django dla Idiotow&quot;
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; book_pl.description = &quot;Django opisane w prostych slowach&quot;
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; book_pl.model = book
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; book_pl.save()
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; 
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; # now here comes the magic
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; book.title_en
<br/>u&#39;Django for Dummies&#39;
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; book.description_pl
<br/>u&#39;Django opisane w prostych slowach&#39;To have it interated with Django Admin nicely, try this: </p>

<p>admin.py </p>

<p>from django.contrib import admin
<br/>import models</p>

<p>class BookTranslationInline(admin.StackedInline):
<br/>   model = models.BookTranslation
<br/>   extra = 1
<br/>   min_num = 1</p>

<p>class BookAdmin(admin.ModelAdmin):
<br/>   list_display = [&quot;ISBN&quot;]
<br/>   inlines = [BookTranslationInline]</p>

<p>admin.site.register(models.Book, BookAdmin)</p>

 title : The django-opendocument Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The script is a class that represents an opendocument. </p>

<p>Currently it can be a spreadsheet or a text document, but it&#39;s deadly easy to add the other types. </p>

<p>It expects a decompressed version of the document in some django template dir (as defined on settings.py). It will render all xml files inside that dir as django templates. </p>

<p>And it can generate an appropriate HttpResponse object. </p>

<p>It has been made for a custom website, and has enough functionality for our needs, so don&#39;t expect it to evolve fast unless you want to contribute. </p>

<p>There is another aproach to generate odt files under django here: </p>

<p>http://www.djangosnippets.org/snippets/15/</p>

 summary : <p>This is basicly a fork of django-openid, with this short list of changes: </p>

<p>python-openid 2.x.x support  SimpleRegistration (redone), Pape and AttributeExchange extenstion support bug fixes from django-openid Issue tracker (special thanks to reporters and patchers. ) Clearer settings and improved docs (my personal opinion, I could be wrong ) Plugable application structure ( thanks to ubernostrum for the slides&amp;advices )  </p>

<p>django-openid-consumer aims to do only one thing, simple OpenID auth( with all the extension s python-openid supports ) for comments on blogs and similar. It doesen&#39;t aim to provide any further integration ( like for example tighter integration with auth ) with Django.</p>

 title : The django-package Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>New approach at http://code.google.com/p/django-reusableapps/Dont miss my weblog at http://jannisleidel.com </p>

<p>########################################################################################## </p>

<p>Please download django-package.diff and patch the current django trunk with it. </p>

<p>wget http://django-package.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/django-package.diff
<br/>cp django-package.diff /path/to/django_src
<br/>cd /path/to/django_src
<br/>patch -p0 &lt; django-package.diffYou can use one new command with django-admin.py to create a standalone application package. You should do this in a blank directory, outside the directory where you manage your other django applications. For now it&#39;s best to develope every application in a seperate directory since each should be installed with setuptools easy_install afterwards. </p>

<p> Revision 17: </p>

<p>again MAJOR overhaul of the code to use more OOP idioms (hell, it&#39;s Python!) better handling of user inputs extensible prompt system, including variable validation only the changed files will be saved when running editapp, except for the txt files (which will never be overwritten) more docstrings wrapping of setuptools&#39; setup() to make sure the default PyPI keyword is included anytime  Revision 15: </p>

<p>incompatible changes after major refactoring of django.core.management docstrings check for invalid app names (like &quot;tests&quot;, &quot;doc&quot; etc) added the question if the app can be zipped (as an egg) use of CommandError from django.core.management.base new reusable applications are now created in a directory with the name of the app, &quot;editapp&quot; still needs to be executed within the application directory and needs the name of the app # tree myapp/
<br/>myapp/
<br/>|-- INSTALL.txt
<br/>|-- MANIFEST.in
<br/>|-- README.txt
<br/>|-- docs
<br/>|-- entries
<br/>|-- format
<br/>|-- myapp
<br/>|   |-- __init__.py
<br/>|   |-- models.py
<br/>|   |-- templates
<br/>|   |   `-- myapp
<br/>|   `-- views.py
<br/>|-- release.py
<br/>|-- setup.py
<br/>`-- tests Revision 9: </p>

<p>Changed a lot on the release engine: </p>

<p>better renaming in the meta data assistent new question for keywords (needed for the Django application repository) rewritten template system for the skeleton files code clean-up </p>

<p> Revision 8: </p>

<p>Fixed application name changing (either with a fresh or with an existing application) and the automatic directory move </p>

<p> I changed with revision 7 the default behaviour of the &quot;startapp&quot; command! </p>

<p>Last changelog: </p>

<p>Greatly enhanced &quot;startapp&quot; and a new &quot;editapp&quot; command to re-edit the meta information in the release.py.
<br/>Error handling: a lot.
<br/>New &quot;--noskeleton&quot; for &quot;startapp&quot; command and changed behaviour when creating a Django application with it:
<br/>it now creates a STANDALONE apps with the skeleton files defined in django.utils.package.
<br/>With the help of &quot;--noskeleton&quot; switch it&#39;s still possible to create plain project based apps.</p>

 summary : <p>This application will allow users of Django-powered websites keep track of the time they spend on different projects.  It&#39;s a work in process. </p>

<p>FeaturesConfigurable: Pendulum can be configured to operate on several Django-powered sites.  The period lengths can be configured as monthly or as a fixed-length period. Projects: You can have an unlimited number of projects to be able to categorize hours spent working on certain tasks.  Each project can be activated/deactivated as necessary via the Django admin. Activities: Activities allow you to further categorize work done on particular tasks for each project. ScreenshotsIf you&#39;re interested in seeing some screenshots of Pendulum, head on over to PendulumScreenshots. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Requirementsdjango-pendulum requires a modern version of the Django framework.  By modern I simply mean a version with the newforms-admin functionality.  If you&#39;re running on Django 1.0 or later, you&#39;re good. </p>

<p>django-pendulum also relies upon the django.contrib.admin, django.contrib.auth, django.contrib.contenttypes, and django.contrib.sites frameworks. </p>

<p>InstallationDownload django-pendulum using one of the following methods: </p>

<p>easy_installYou can download the package from the CheeseShop or use  </p>

<p>easy_install django-pendulumto download and install django-pendulum. </p>

<p>Package DownloadDownload the latest .tar.gz file from the downloads section and extract it somewhere you&#39;ll remember.  Use python setup.py install to install it. </p>

<p>Checkout from SubversionExecute the following command (or use the equivalent function in a GUI such as TortoiseSVN), and make sure you&#39;re checking Pendulum out somewhere on the PYTHONPATH. </p>

<p>svn co http://django-pendulum.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/pendulum pendulumVerifying InstallationThe easiest way to ensure that you have successfully installed Pendulum is to execute a command such as: </p>

<p>python -c &quot;import pendulum; pendulum.get_version()&quot;If that displays the version of Pendulum that you tried to install, you&#39;re good to roll.  If you see something other than that, you probably need to check your PYTHONPATH environment variable. </p>

<p>ConfigurationFirst of all, you must add this project to your list of INSTALLED_APPS in settings.py: </p>

<p>INSTALLED_APPS = (
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.admin&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.auth&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.contenttypes&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sessions&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sites&#39;,
<br/>    ...
<br/>    &#39;pendulum&#39;,
<br/>    ...
<br/>)Run manage.py syncdb.  This creates a few tables in your database that are necessary for operation. </p>

<p>Next, you should add an entry to your main urls.py file.  For example: </p>

<p>from django.conf.urls.defaults import *</p>

<p>from django.contrib import admin
<br/>admin.autodiscover()</p>

<p>urlpatterns = patterns(&#39;&#39;,
<br/>    (r&#39;^admin/(.*)&#39;, admin.site.root),
<br/>    (r&#39;^pendulum/&#39;, include(&#39;pendulum.urls&#39;)),
<br/>)The next thing you will want to do is configure Pendulum for the active Django sites.  Do this by going into the Django admin and clicking the &quot;add&quot; link next to Pendulum Configurations. </p>

<p>The first step in the configuration is to choose which site this particular configuration will apply to.  The decision is easy if you only have one site :) </p>

<p>Next, you must choose what kind of &quot;accounting period&quot; you wish to use.  If you want month-long periods, ensure the &quot;Is monthly&quot; check box is selected.  Then enter the day of the month that the periods begin.  Periods that begin on the first of the month will always range from midnight on the first of each month to 11:59:59 PM on the last day of each month.  Periods that begin on the 16th of the month will range from midnight on the 16th of each month to 11:59:59 PM on the 15th of the following month.  Be wise about choosing start days such as the 31st of the month--it&#39;s not a wise choice no matter what situation you&#39;re in. </p>

<p>Alternatively, you may choose fixed-length accounting periods.  The installation date does not necessarily have to be the actual installation date.  This field is used as a reference point for creating periods.  For example, if you have 2-week long accounting periods that begin on Sundays and end two Saturdays later, you would select any Sunday from any month from any year.  Then you would enter 14 for the period length.  Periods will automatically be constructed that will begin at midnight each Sunday and end at 11:59:59 PM two Saturdays in the future. </p>

<p>If you fail to configure Pendulum for a given site, you will likely receive HTTP 500 errors if you try to access Pendulum via the front-end. </p>

<p>Add ProjectsNext, you should add at least one project to Pendulum.  This can easily be accomplished via the Django admin.  The same goes for activities, but these are not required. </p>

<p>PermissionsFinally, be sure set people up with the appropriate permissions using Django&#39;s Auth framework.  The front end side of Pendulum respects these permissions.  That means that if a user doesn&#39;t have the permission to clock in, the will be presented with a login screen (even if they&#39;re logged in already) when they try to clock in on the front end site.  The same goes for other operations such as pausing/unpausing entries, updating entries, deleting entries, etc. </p>

<p>An easy way to assign the same Pendulum permissions to several users is to create a Group using the Auth framework.  There is a custom command for creating a group with all of the permissions necessary for the front end, including the ability to: </p>

<p>add entries update entries delete entries clock in clock out pause/unpause entries To use this command, simply run ./manage.py create_pendulum_group.  You may run ./manage.py help create_pendulum_group to learn about options for this command. </p>

<p>The Date FieldI&#39;ve been hesitant to do anything to make the date/time fields more user-friendly when adding or updating entries.  I don&#39;t want to tie anyone down to my particular way of doing things.  I personally prefer jQuery for this sort of thing, but I do realize that jQuery disgusts many other people out there.  Therefore, the first versions of the application didn&#39;t come with anything to make those fields easier to use and understand. </p>

<p>However, that seems to be the most common complaint amongst those who have played with the application--the lack of user-friendly date pickers.  As such, I have added some jQuery-based utilities to make choosing a date easier and more intuitive. </p>

<p>By default, the application will expect to find the appropriate files in a directory called pendulum within your media directory.  All you should need to do is copy or symlink the media folder from the Pendulum application directory.  If you copy the media folder, rename it to pendulum.  If you create a symlink to Pendulum&#39;s media folder, make sure the symlink is called pendulum.  This directory should hold all of the necessary files to make the date picker work. </p>

<p>In your add_update_entry.html template (if you override the default ones), make sure you have a code block such as: </p>

<p>{% block extra-head %}
<br/>{{ form.media }}</p>

<p>$(document).ready(function () {
<br/>    $(&#39;input.vDateField&#39;).datepicker({
<br/>            dateFormat: $.datepicker.W3C,
<br/>            showOn: &#39;both&#39;,
<br/>            buttonImage: &#39;{{ MEDIA_URL }}pendulum/img/calendar.png&#39;,
<br/>            buttonImageOnly: true
<br/>        });
<br/>});</p>

<p>{% endblock %}This is just jQuery&#39;s way of attaching the date picker to the appropriate fields. </p>

<p>Customizing The Date PickerI tried to put some utilities in the application to allow you to change the date picker that is used with ease.  There is a variable that you can define in your settings.py file to override the default date picker: PENDULUM_DATE_MEDIA.  If you simply want to change the styling CSS,, for example, you could use this variable.  The default value is: </p>

<p>PENDULUM_DATE_MEDIA = {
<br/>    &#39;js&#39;: (settings.MEDIA_URL + &#39;pendulum/js/jquery.js&#39;,
<br/>            settings.MEDIA_URL + &#39;pendulum/js/jquery.ui.js&#39;),
<br/>    &#39;css&#39;: {
<br/>        &#39;all&#39;: (settings.MEDIA_URL + &#39;pendulum/css/jquery-ui.css&#39;,)
<br/>    }
<br/>}You can see that it is a dictionary with two keys: js and css.  The values of these two items conform to the concepts outlined in Django&#39;s documentation.  Changing the values within PENDULUM_DATE_MEDIA should permit you to completely remove or replace the date picker as you desire.</p>
 title : The django-pendulum Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The django-photoportal Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Photo portal with RSS, Friends, PM&#39;s</p>
 summary : <p>Django-Picasso</p>

<p>Note:This is an inactive project that was made mostly obsolete by the continued development of django-syncr.  This project is in the process of being combined with django-picasa to become a reference implementation of Picasa as a photo app backend using django-syncr.  The working copy of the combination can be found on the project&#39;s Bitbucket page.  The django-picasso project will likely be deleted from Google Code in the near future. </p>

<p>IntroductionI love Google&#39;s Picasa desktop application, and the ability to upload photos to the Picasa Web Albums site using the app is extremely useful.  When I built my personal website using Django, I wanted a way to use Picasa Web Albums as a backend for my photos section so that I could take advantage of the easy uploads.  I couldn&#39;t find a Django pluggable app that fit what I was looking for, so I decided to go ahead and make one using the Picasa Web Albums API and the GData Python client. </p>

<p>AboutDjango-Picasso is a relatively simply way to synchronize data from the Picasa Web Albums API into your local database and use it in your web application.  It does this using a script that integrates the GData Python client and a set of Django models.  This script can be called from the custom management command that I built and run from a cron job, or for more flexibility it can be imported and run directly from picasso.utils.  The script does not import the actual picture files - it saves links to the pictures hosted on the Picasa Web Albums site. </p>

<p>If you find this project useful and modify it to add features, please consider sharing those enhancements by adding a patch to an issue ticket.  I&#39;ll review and apply the enhancement to the trunk so that it can be shared with the community.  Thanks! </p>

<p>PrerequisitesDjango-Picasso requires the GData Python Client, which can be downloaded here. </p>

<p>Debian/Ubuntu users: I tried to install the python-gdata package from apt-get, but it did not provide the same functionality.  I wasn&#39;t able to import gdata.photos.service.PhotoService(), which is what I use in the utility script.  I had to install the python client using the link above and the included setup.py script. </p>

<p>InstallationInstallation is detailed in the wiki.</p>
 title : The django-picasso Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The django-pipe-middleware Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Usage </p>

<p>1.regist middleware in settings.py </p>

<p>2.add pipe settings to your urls.py &quot;&quot;&quot;urls.py&quot;&quot;&quot; #some url description... </p>

<p>urlpatterns += patterns(&#39;yourproject.yourapp.views&#39;, </p>

<p>(r&#39;^test$&#39;, &#39;test&#39;), 
<br/>) </p>

<p>import pipe_middleware </p>

<p>pipepatterns = pipe_middleware.patterns(&#39;&#39;, </p>

<p>(r&#39;^test$&#39;, &#39;cat&#39;, {&#39;-n&#39;: &#39;&#39;}), 
<br/>) </p>

<p>3.done. you&#39;ll get numbering response. (because response string piped by &quot;cat -n&quot;)</p>
 title : The django-podcast Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django-podcast is a Django application that allows you to easily publish podcasts that conform to the RSS 2.0 and iTunes RSS podcast specifications. </p>

<p>Update 2009/03/05: This project has, like all of the cool Django apps, moved to GitHub. The code here will be available for archival purposes, but for the latest, get on over to GitHub, fork, contribute, and all that good stuff. </p>

<p>Django and Python versiondjango-podcast requires at least Django 0.97 revision 7967. This revision incorporated the newforms-admin branch into trunk and makes the most notable use of it in the categories class of the application&#39;s models. However, I heavily encourage you to develop with the Django development version (known as &quot;trunk&quot;), which is Django 1.0.x at the time of this writing. At the least, please use Django 1.0. </p>

<p>If you&#39;re developing on a web host, Python is probably already installed. To check, type python from the command line after logging in via SSH. If Python isn&#39;t installed, download and install Python. At least Python version 2.3 is recommended. </p>

<p>ssh user@domain.com 
<br/>     </p>

<p>python </p>

<p>InstallationAfter connecting to your server via SSH, typically you download Django and other packages into a source directory. You would then symlink the django directory to a location that resides on your Python path. Likewise, download django-podcast from the Google Code Subversion repository and symlink the podcast directory. </p>

<p>If you work with WebFaction (like I do), and assuming one location on your Python path is $HOME/webapps/django/lib/python2.5, it might go like: </p>

<p>mkdir ~/source 
<br/>svn co http://code.djangoproject.com/svn/django/trunk/ $HOME/source/django-trunk/ 
<br/>ln -s $HOME/source/django-trunk/django/ $HOME/webapps/django/lib/python2.5/django 
<br/>svn co http://django-podcast.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ $HOME/source/django-podcast-read-only/ 
<br/>ln -s $HOME/source/django-podcast-read-only/podcast/ $HOME/webapps/django/lib/python2.5/podcast 
<br/>Add podcast as a tuple item to your INSTALLED_APPS in settings.py: </p>

<p>    INSTALLED_APPS = (
<br/>      ...
<br/>      &#39;podcast&#39;,
<br/>      ...
<br/>    )Add these lines to your URL configuration, urls.py: </p>

<p>    urlpatterns += patterns(&#39;&#39;, 
<br/>        (r&#39;^podcasts/&#39;, include(&#39;podcast.urls&#39;)),
<br/>    )Run the syncdb command from the directory in which your settings.py resides, most probably your applications&#39; project directory. Again, if you&#39;re on WebFaction like I am, where example-project is your project name: </p>

<p>cd ~/webapps/django/example-project/ 
<br/>     </p>

<p>python manage.py syncdb </p>

<p>Alternatively if the Django binary directory is on your Python path, run the syncdb command from any directory to install the database tables. </p>

<p>django-admin.py syncdb 
<br/>If you installed the Django admin application, you should be able to see the podcast application&#39;s show and episode areas: </p>

<p>http://www.example.com/admin/podcast/ 
<br/>You might need to restart the server for changes to take effect, especially if you are running Django on mod_python. </p>

<p>DependenciesNone. However, consider a thumbnail creation utility, such as sorl-thumbnail, if you are not in control of creating your podcast show artwork. iTunes suggests show artwork should be a width and height of 600 pixels, but you might want to reduce the size of artwork on your website. </p>

<p>Web site URLsThe default, out-of-the-box Web site URLs should look something like: </p>

<p>http://www.example.com/podcasts/ 
<br/>     </p>

<p>http://www.example.com/podcasts/title-of-show/ 
<br/>     http://www.example.com/podcasts/title-of-show/title-of-episode/ </p>

<p>The /podcasts/ portion of the URL is hard coded into the URL configuration. Beautifully designed default templates are included, so feel free to show off your URLs after saving a show and an episode! Note that the templates were not stress tested in Internet Explorer 6 or 7, but work on Web standards browsers. </p>

<p>FeedBurner and iTunes URLsAfter saving at least one show and one episode, consider submitting your feed URL to FeedBurner for keeping track of podcast subscriber statistics. Your feed URL should be something like, where title-of-show is the slug of your show: </p>

<p>http://www.example.com/podcasts/title-of-show/feed/ 
<br/>Remember to check the checkbox for &quot;I&#39;m a podcaster!&quot; Your new FeedBurner URL should be something like: </p>

<p>http://feeds.feedburner.com/TitleOfShow 
<br/>You can now return to your website&#39;s admin and paste this URL into your Show&#39;s FeedBurner textbox. For bonus points, submit your FeedBurner URL to the iTunes Store. Your iTunes podcast URL should then be something like: </p>

<p>http://phobos.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/viewPodcast?id=000000000 
<br/>The advantage of submitting your FeedBurner URL to the iTunes Store allows you to track show statistics while also giving users the advantage of using the friendly iTunes interface. Return to the admin again and paste the iTunes show URL into the Show&#39;s iTunes URL textbox. Promote either the FeedBurner URL or the iTunes URL using each respective template tag on your website (in the simplest example): </p>

<p>{{ show.feedburner }} 
<br/>     </p>

<p>{{ show.itunes }} </p>

<p>Ping iTunes for new contentThe iTunes Store checks new content daily but you might want to make a new episode available immediately in the iTunes Store. Visit your show&#39;s ping URL to make that episode available, which would be something like: </p>

<p>https://phobos.apple.com/WebObjects/MZFinance.woa/wa/pingPodcast?id=000000000 
<br/>Alternatively, if you&#39;re a savvy developer, you could set up a cron job to handle this, but note that pinging too often could result in a removal from the iTunes Store. </p>

<p>Yahoo! Media RSS feed submissionLikewise, considering submitting your podcast to Yahoo! Search, which specifically accepts any kind of regularly published media-based (audio, video, image, document, etc.) RSS 2.0 feed or Media RSS feed. </p>

<p>Your Media RSS feed should be something like: </p>

<p>http://www.example.com/podcasts/title-of-show/media/ 
<br/>Google video sitemapsIf you&#39;re creating a video podcast, you can submit a video sitemap to Google Webmaster Tools. The video sitemap will help Google index videos in Google Video. </p>

<p>After a successful installation, the video sitemap URL should be something like: </p>

<p>http://www.example.com/podcasts/title-of-show/sitemap.xml 
<br/>Additionally, you can add the video sitemap URL to your robots.txt file. </p>

<p>Sitemap: http://www.example.com/podcasts/title-of-show/sitemap.xml 
<br/>Google allows the submission of a media RSS feed instead of the sitemap to Google Webmaster Tools if you prefer. </p>

<p>Relevant linksSome URLs that helped me and could help you: </p>

<p>SpecificationsRSS 2.0 specification Apple iTunes podcast technical specification Media RSS 2.0 Module specification Google Video Media RSS Specification Atom syndication format specification Google video sitemaps Tutorials, Validators, SoftwareComparing Media RSS formats Webmonkey&#39;s &quot;Use Media RSS&quot; Apple iTunes podcasts Apple iTunes audio podcasts Apple iTunes video podcasts Apple iTunes HD podcasts Feed Validator MetaX, Macintosh meta-data tagger (for saving episode-specific artwork and other meta data) For the curious, django-podcast is compatible with enhanced podcasts and HD podcasts; both depend on the respective file&#39;s preparation and not on the feeds. </p>

<p>LicensingThis software is licensed under the new BSD license. </p>

<p>SupportPlease file a ticket if you find a problem with this application, and if you&#39;re feeling generous a patch to go with it. Help me help you! </p>

<p>If you used this Django application, I&#39;d love to see it in action, and if you have suggestions or feature requests, drop me a line at rich (at) richardcornish (dot) com and let me know.</p>
 title : The django-poormanscron Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Django Poor Man&#39;s Cron is Django app which makes use of spambots, search engine indexing robots and alike to run scheduled tasks in approximately regular intervals. </p>

<p>This app isn&#39;t meant to be a fully-featured project, but rather a modifiable experimental concept. </p>

<p>To install the app, do the following: </p>

<p>Check it out and put it somewhere under python path. Add the app to INSTALLED_APPS and its PoorMansCronMiddleware class to MIDDLEWARE_CLASSES in your project settings. Run python manage.py syncdb to update the DB schema. Create management commands for scheduled tasks (probably you can also use Django Command Extensions). Create ScheduledTask objects in Django administration. </p>

<p>INSTALLED_APPS = (
<br/>    # ...
<br/>    &quot;poormanscron&quot;,
<br/>    )</p>

<p>MIDDLEWARE_CLASSES = (
<br/>    # ...
<br/>    &quot;poormanscron.middleware.PoorMansCronMiddleware&quot;,
<br/>    )The included initial_data fixture serves as an example where &quot;cleanup&quot; command is called every day after 3 am.</p>

 title : The django-positions Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This module provides PositionField, a model field for Django that allows instances of a model to be sorted by a user-specified position.  Conceptually, the field works like a list index: when the position of one item is changed, the positions of other items in the collection are updated in response. </p>

<p>The source code is available on GitHub.</p>
 summary : <p>Personalized URLs (PURLs) have been an upcoming marketing tactic for a few years now. This technology combines the use of variable printing on direct mail pieces which incorporates a PURL. Recipients of the piece then visit their very own personalized website. </p>

<p>There are many projects out there that use PURLs and they are all rather expensive. This project hopes to make it easier for Django developers to make their own PURLs.</p>

 title : The django-rabid-ratings Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django-rabid-ratingsA port of Michelle Steigerwalt&#39;s rabid ratings star rating ajax component to be plugged into a django project as a django app. </p>

<p>Uses mootools-1.2.0-core instead of 1.2dev </p>

<p>An example can be viewed at http://factory-h.com/ratingstest/ </p>

<p>DownloadingThe best way to obtain this project is to get it from subversion: </p>

<p>svn checkout http://django-rabid-ratings.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/rabidratings rabidratings 
<br/>UsingFollow the instructions in README.txt to install.  After installing, there are three steps to using the ratings component: </p>

<p>1. Import the template tags: </p>

<p>{% load rabidratings_extras %} </p>

<p>2. Add the required css and js files with this tag in your </p>

<p> section </p>

<p>{% rating_header %} </p>

<p>3. Add the rating component, the first argument is a &#39;key&#39; to uniquely identify the item you are rating. </p>

<p>{% show_rating &#39;1234&#39; %}</p>

 title : The django-regions Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The django-reploc Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django-reploc is a project that allows you to install a Google Map on your site to display and filter &quot;representatives&quot; for your site. These representatives may be dealers/vendors for your products, your friends or business associates, or just places you&#39;ve been and want to advertise. I built the application to be a dealer locator, but I realize the value in an application like this and tried to make it as generic as possible. </p>

<p>FeaturesUnlimited number of representatives. Unlimited number of locations per representative. Automatic latitude/longitude determination for locations.  If there&#39;s a problem determining the coordinates to the address, you can enter them manually. Locations can have &quot;attributes.&quot;  This is a way of specifying, for example, which locations carry which lines of your products. You can decide whether you want to use JavaScript or Python to do the heavy lifting. Users can search for locations within a radius of an address they specify. Offer your users driving directions to various representative locations. Requirementsdjango-reploc requires at least Django 1.0.  For automatic coordinate determination, django-reploc requires the geopy library.  This can be installed using easy_install geopy.  The application also requires that you have a Google Maps API key.  To get one of those, simply go to the Google Maps API page and fill out the necessary information.  Finally, django-reploc relies heavily upon jQuery in order to operate.  I used the latest version of jQuery, which is currently 1.2.6. </p>

<p>InstallationDownload django-reploc using one of the following methods: </p>

<p>easy_installYou can download the package from the CheeseShop or use </p>

<p>easy_install django-replocto download and install django-reploc. </p>

<p>Package DownloadDownload the latest .tar.gz file from the downloads section and extract it somewhere you&#39;ll remember.  Use python setup.py install to install it. </p>

<p>Checkout from SubversionExecute the following command (or use the equivalent function in a GUI such as TortoiseSVN), and make sure you&#39;re checking Pendulum out somewhere on the PYTHONPATH. </p>

<p>svn co http://django-reploc.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/reploc replocVerifying InstallationThe easiest way to ensure that you have successfully installed Pendulum is to execute a command such as: </p>

<p>python -c &quot;import reploc; print reploc.get_version()&quot;If that displays the version of django-reploc that you tried to install, you&#39;re good to roll.  If you see something other than that, you probably need to check your PYTHONPATH environment variable. </p>

<p>ConfigurationFirst of all, you must add this project to your list of INSTALLED_APPS in settings.py: </p>

<p>INSTALLED_APPS = (
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.admin&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.auth&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.contenttypes&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sessions&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sites&#39;,
<br/>    ...
<br/>    &#39;reploc&#39;,
<br/>    ...
<br/>)Next you should add the context processor to your TEMPLATE_CONTEXT_PROCESSORS setting so the templates have access to the Google Maps API key.  You don&#39;t really need this step if you&#39;re going to put the API key straight into your template. </p>

<p>TEMPLATE_CONTEXT_PROCESSORS = (
<br/>    &#39;django.core.context_processors.auth&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.core.context_processors.i18n&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.core.context_processors.media&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;reploc.context_processors.representatives&#39;,
<br/>)Define your Google Maps API key in your settings.py file </p>

<p>GOOGLE_MAPS_KEY = &#39;sdfsafasfdasfdasdf&#39;Additionally, you may specify whether you would like the grunt work (distance calculations and whatnot) handled by JavaScript or Python: </p>

<p>REPLOC_USE_JS = FalseThis will probably never be used much, but it&#39;s there just in case.  The application defaults to using JavaScript. </p>

<p>Run manage.py syncdb.  This creates a few tables in your database that are necessary for operation. </p>

<p>Next, you should add an entry to your main urls.py file.  For example: </p>

<p>from django.conf.urls.defaults import *</p>

<p>from django.contrib import admin
<br/>admin.autodiscover()</p>

<p>urlpatterns = patterns(&#39;&#39;,
<br/>    (r&#39;^admin/(.*)&#39;, admin.site.root),
<br/>    (r&#39;^locator/&#39;, include(&#39;reploc.urls&#39;)),
<br/>)Finally, you&#39;ll probably want to copy the media files that I use in django-reploc, unless you have some of your own.  Those files can be found in the /media/ directory of the project.  There are really only two files that you should need to copy to your media directory: reploc/media/js/jquery-1.3.1.min.js and reploc/media/img/ajax.gif (see http://code.google.com/p/django-reploc/source/browse/#svn/trunk/reploc/media for the specific files).  Alternatively, you may just override the templates to use whatever you want.  I make no guarantees that the application will still work if you do that though ;) </p>

<p>UsageAs soon as you have all of the configuration taken care of, simply fire up your site (or restart it) and jump into the Django administration interface.  You can add locations straight from the &quot;Add Representative&quot; page if you&#39;d like.  When you&#39;re done, head on over to http://www.yourwebsite.com/locator/ (or whatever it happens to be in your case) to see the application in action. </p>

<p>Updating Location CoordinatesI&#39;ve created a utility to help you update the location coordinates if you feel the need.  They should be updated each time you save a location, but if you want to update all of the locations in one swing, you can use the command ./manage.py reploc_update_coords.</p>
 title : The django-richtext Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django-richtextRich Text Editors can be painful to install and configure, even with the powerful Django Framework.  </p>

<p>django-richtext lets you easily have a rich text editor for any of your django model fields or form fields. It&#39;s basically a set of custom form fields that make it a piece of cake to have rich text, anywhere, in django. </p>

<p>How it&#39;s usedExample Django Model: </p>

<p>class Blog(models.Model):
<br/>    content = AdminRichTextField()Example Django Form: </p>

<p>class ContactForm(forms.Form):
<br/>    message = RichTextField()Photologue users:django-richtext also optionally integrates with the popular photo management solution photologue. So if you use photologue then you&#39;ll like this even more. When you click to insert an image, a window pops up asking you to choose a Photo Size and a Photo. You make your selection and it automatically sticks the correct sized photo into your text editor.</p>
 title : The django-roulade Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Roulade allows you to create &quot;tumblelogs&quot; that can aggregate any of your models into one simple list. It was written when I wanted to use jellyroll, but didn&#39;t like the idea of defining models for storing roll items, much less the concept of providers - which, for my purposes, was stepping on the toes of the apps that are already in my project anyway. I also wasn&#39;t especially thrilled about changing my models to have specific fields just to be jellyroll compatible either. Roulade requires no models of its own, and is flexible enough to follow a non-model based data source if you&#39;re into the &quot;provider&quot; thing anyway. However, borrowing a phrase from the jellyroll wiki, &quot;It&#39;s also extremely not done yet.&quot;</p>
 summary : <p>django-rstify - A restructured text filter for django templatesdjango-rstify is a set of template filters to provide easy conversion from restructured text to HTML. Besides this basic functionality this application allows you to highlight sourcecode snippets inside your text using the pygments library. </p>

<p>Note: Django already provides a simple restructured text filter. If you don&#39;t need the extras in this application, I recommend to use the core version. </p>

<p>DownloadThe main repository of this app is located on Github. You can easily checkout the latest version using git: </p>

<p>git clone git://github.com/bartTC/django-rstify.git  or download this app as a .tar.gz file. See Links on the right side for download links. </p>

<p>How to use it in templatesTo convert a restructured text from an object to HTML simply apply the rstify filter on it: </p>

<p>{% load rstify_tags %}</p>

<p>{{ entry.content|rstify }}If you want to convert inline content, use the filter templatetag around: </p>

<p>{% load rstify_tags %}</p>

<p>{% filter rstify %}
<br/>This is some *restructured text*.
<br/>{% endfilter %}How to use it in sourcecodeApplying this filter inside your code is easy: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; from rstify import rstify
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt;
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; print rstify(&#39;This is *restructured text*.&#39;)
<br/>This is restructured text.</p>

<p>Initial Header LevelBy default the initial heading in your restructured text becomes a </p>

<p> in HTML: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; header = &#39;&#39;&#39;
<br/>... ================
<br/>... This is a Header
<br/>... ================
<br/>... &#39;&#39;&#39;
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; print rstify(header)</p>

<p>This is a Header
<br/>You can override this by setting the initial_header_level to an integer from 1 to 6: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; print rstify(header, initial_header_level=3)</p>

<p>This is a Header
<br/>In your template just set this as the first option of the rstify filter: </p>

<p>{{ entry.content|rstify:&quot;3&quot; }}Syntax Highlightingdjango-rstify provides syntax highlighting using the pygments library. To highlight parts of your restructured text, simply put it in a sourcecode directive: </p>

<p>Here is some text. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit.
<br/>Integer porttitor nulla sed dui. Aenean lorem mi, tincidunt et, porttitor
<br/>nec, condimentum venenatis, felis. Maecenas ornare blandit leo.</p>

<p>.. sourcecode:: python</p>

<p>    def foo(bar):
<br/>        return bar*2</p>

<p>Continue with text. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit.
<br/>Integer porttitor nulla sed dui. Aenean lorem mi, tincidunt et, porttitor nec,
<br/>condimentum venenatis, felis. Maecenas ornare blandit leo.Pygments provides a bunch of highlighters (also called lexer), just replace python with a lexer of your choice. Here is a complete set of available lexers. Read pygments styles how to colorize the output using css.</p>

 summary : <p>This project is a pastebin for formatted displaying of restructered text.</p>

 title : The django-scrumtool Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project is on hiatus. It won&#39;t be maintained in the near future. </p>

<p>PurposeBackward incompatible change! As of r14 code requires newforms-admin branch! </p>

<p>This project will create simple (mean easy to use and not disturbing) but effective Scrum management tool for distributed Scrum teams made using Django (with newforms-admin) and Ajax with jQuery. It will have: </p>

<p>multiple projects and teams stories for project with file attachments sprints with tasks and their descriptions burndown chart stories and tasks with history of changes per project impediments tags for stories There will be admin interface for all this (basic version already done) but the standard Django admin is not the best way to do fast and simple Scrum management, so there will be a dashboard for stories and tasks management powered by Ajax to simplify day by day work with the tool. Creation of sprints, projects, impediments and user management will stay on admin level, because it is not done every day! </p>

<p>RequirementsDjango SVN (newforms-admin branch) - tested on revision 7815 django-tagging (trunk version) on Python path googlecharts (tip) on Python path DoneDB model with Admin options saving history of changes for tasks and backlog items (for burn down chart generation) To doviews &amp; templates view tests burn down chart for sprints historical data analysis (for past and current velocity measurement)</p>
 summary : <p>A couple of days ago, we discussed ideas of realizing a completely pluggable search app, which requires no modification of the existing apps, models and DB. This is in fact a question for Wheel 2.0, but in times of Mythbusters and DIY, reinventing the wheel seems to be fun, and sometimes required for understanding the basic mechanics of a matter. </p>

<p>For further information, read on in the wiki starting here: http://code.google.com/p/django-search-app/wiki/WikiHome </p>

<p>We&#39;re totally looking forward to any comments, thoughts, contributions, suggestions and links (especially like: “This is done already! Look here: …”).  </p>

<p>UPDATE: </p>

<p>We created a first Prototype, that full-fills most of our wishes.  </p>

<p>It is totally pluggable Works without any modification of existing code provides mechanisms to define ranking-rules based on models transform any third-party model to be useful in your search view without touching them define appearance of the results per model We won&#39;t publish this version, as is it just meant to evaluate our ideas. But stay tuned!</p>

 title : The django-session-messages Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project was intended to fill the gap until Django had anonymous session-based transient messages. With the release of 1.2 it will, therefore this project becomes deprecated. </p>

<p>The code here borrows quite a bit from the patch on Django ticket 4604, but is somewhat lighter because it doesn&#39;t attempt to transparently integrate Django&#39;s current user-based message system with anonymous messages.  The session-based messages are handled separately. </p>

<p>Documentation of this application can be found in the docs/ subdirectory, or online.</p>

 title : The django-simple-comments Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Why another comment app?Quite simply, I find django.contrib.comments bloated, clunky and lacking some major features.  One feature of django-simple-comments that&#39;s inspired by django.contrib.comments is the ability to attach a comment to absolutely any object of any type, thanks to the fantastic Content Types Framework.  Most everything else has been coded from the ground up. </p>

<p>Furthermore, I think django.contrib.comments is missing key features like Akismet and email notifications.  I realize comment_utils will do this, but I don&#39;t particularly like the idea of having to depend on another app just to get full functionality of the first app.  I&#39;d rather have a simple comments app that does what I need all by itself. </p>

<p>Update: New django.contrib.commentsA new version of django.contrib.comments has been merged into Django trunk.  It&#39;s significantly better than the old version, and there are a number of similarities between the new version and django-simple-comments.  However, I plan to continue development of django-simple-comments for a few reasons: </p>

<p>django.contrib.comments doesn&#39;t have built-in supprt for Akismet.  I realize it&#39;s possible to do this with Signals, but I want Akismet to be built-in to the app itself so that anytime I need to use it I simply add the API key to settings.py instead of having a separate signals.py to include with every project. I like having Approved / Moderate / Spam statues as opposed to &#39;is_public&#39; and &#39;is_removed&#39; boolean flags. This app has more robust feed generation (something I&#39;m planning to contribute back to contrib.comments) This will have built in support for &quot;Remember my info&quot; and &quot;Email me follow up comments&quot; checkboxes. I realize it&#39;s possible to extend contrib.comments to have these abilities, but again I want one app that does all this.  I don&#39;t want to manage multiple apps or files just to have fully functioning comments. </p>

<p>Current featuresFlag comments as approved, moderated or spam. Automatic feeds for all comments, comments for a specific content type, and comments for a specific object, like so: /feeds/comments/ =&gt; Feed of all latest comments /feeds/comments/blog.Post/ =&gt; Feed for latest comments on all blog Posts /feeds/comments/blog.Post/1/ =&gt; Feed for all comments on blog Post with ID = 1 &quot;Remember me&quot; ability to pre-populate form based on User info or sessions (for anonymous users) Automatic spam detection with Akismet Future featuresMost of these already exist in other projects I&#39;ve done and are in the process of being ported into this app. </p>

<p>&quot;Email me follow-up comments&quot; ability Email object author when comments are placed on an object. Addition of options (auto-approve, blacklist, spamlist), possibly using dbsettings Basic useNote: django-simple-comments is being developed with future compatibility in mind, so you&#39;ll need a recent 1.0 Beta version of Django. </p>

<p>Add &quot;comments&quot;, to INSTALLED_APPS Add `&quot;comments.context_processors.user_info&#39;,&quot; to TEMPLATE_CONTEXT_PROCESSORS Add (r&#39;^comments/&#39;, include(&#39;comments.urls&#39;)), to your URLCONF Add {% comment_form  %} into a template to display the comment form. That&#39;s it!  Examples of other features will be added in the near future. </p>

<p>Bugs and feature requestsPlease submit bugs, feature requests and feedback using the Issue Tracker here on Google Code.</p>

 title : The django-smileys Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django-smileys is an application that allows your Django-powered site to display those annoying and useless smileys whenever the smileys filter a pattern that you specify.  This application serves a very simple purpose, but its uses can go beyond that of merely inserting smileys whenever a particular pattern (like &quot;:)&quot; or &quot;;)&quot;).  It can replace whatever pattern you want with an image of your choosing.  There&#39;s gotta be something useful in that, right? </p>

<p>This application can make your blog, forums, photo galleries, user comments, etc a little more interesting, and it&#39;s very simple to install.  Free icon sets plague the Internet, and you can choose whatever icons you&#39;d like to use! </p>

<p>FeaturesStrict pattern matching: you can specify very strict patterns for your smileys Regular expression pattern matching: if you need a little more power in your pattern matching capabilities, you can specify that your patterns are regular expressions (on a per-smiley basis) and the filter should know what to do. RequirementsThis application was built on Django 1.0.2, and it should work with any version of Django that uses the admin.site.register method for telling the Django admin that a model should appear in the admin (as opposed to the class Admin: method). </p>

<p>InstallationDownload django-smileys using one of the following methods: </p>

<p>Checkout from Subversionsvn co http://django-smileys.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/smileys smileysPackage DownloadDownload the latest .tar.gz file from the downloads section and extract it somewhere you&#39;ll remember. </p>

<p>ConfigurationFirst of all, you must add this project to your list of INSTALLED_APPS in settings.py: </p>

<p>INSTALLED_APPS = (
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.admin&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.auth&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.contenttypes&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sessions&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sites&#39;,
<br/>    ...
<br/>    &#39;smileys&#39;,
<br/>    ...
<br/>)Run manage.py syncdb.  This creates a the table in your database that is necessary for operation. </p>

<p>UsageOpen the template file that you want to have your smileys appear in and make sure it has something like this in it: </p>

<p>{% load smiley_tags %}</p>

<p>{% block content %}
<br/>{{ some_content_var|smileys }}
<br/>{% endblock %}The smiley_tags library provides you with a smileys filter, which will examine your database for all active smileys.  It then runs though some_content_var (in this example) and replaces the patterns it finds with the respective smileys.  Pretty simple huh! </p>

<p>And useless! w00t.</p>

<p>Maintained by Retta Inc web studio</p>
 title : The django-socialkit Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The django-sprites Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CSS sprite maps are a Good Thing(tm). The advantages of using a CSS sprite map versus image slicing are well defined by Yahoo&#39;s Exceptional Performance team.  </p>

<p>The problem? CSS sprites maps are very brittle. Creating and maintaining the CSS and images by hand is tedious and error prone. </p>

<p>Django Sprites changes that. Django Sprites hooks into django&#39;s template engine to give designers an easy way of managing sprite maps inside of existing stylesheets. Django Sprites also uses the Python Imaging Library to generate the actual sprite image map itself. By generating both the stylesheet and the image map, updating the sprite map is quick and easy. </p>

<p>We aim to have our first release sometime in Summer 2009 </p>

<p>Note: The project is not dead. Please see this issue for a discussion of development in the short term.</p>
 title : The django-stateful Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>What is it?A revolutionary approach to web applications using django. Code your views using linear flow logic, maintaining the state across requests. Similar to UnCommon web, Seaside and Borges </p>

<p>Since its just another django app, you can still write some views in the traditional style, and use all the features of django web framework. </p>

<p>the other home of this project is http://woobiz.com.ar/en/articles/stateful-django </p>

<p>The kind of code you end up writing:A counter: </p>

<p>class Counter(StatefulView):
<br/>    def main(self):
<br/>        for c in count():
<br/>            yield Page(&quot;you&#39;ve been here %s times before&quot; % c)A wizard (kind of): </p>

<p>class NameForm(forms.Form):
<br/>    name = forms.CharField(max_length=100)
<br/>    
<br/>class LanguageForm(forms.Form):
<br/>    langs = [(x,x) for x in [&#39;python&#39;,&#39;perl&#39;,&#39;ruby&#39;,&#39;php&#39;,&#39;prolog&#39;]]
<br/>    lang = forms.ChoiceField(choices=langs, initial=&#39;python&#39;, widget=forms.RadioSelect)
<br/>    
<br/>class Wizard(StatefulView):
<br/>    def main(self):
<br/>        started = datetime.now()
<br/>        
<br/>        form = NameForm()
<br/>        name = None
<br/>        while not name:
<br/>            input, a, kw = yield show_page(&#39;ask_name.html&#39;, {&#39;form&#39;: form,})
<br/>            form = NameForm(input.GET)
<br/>            if form.is_valid():
<br/>                name = form.cleaned_data[&#39;name&#39;]
<br/>                
<br/>        form = LanguageForm()
<br/>        input, a, kw = yield show_page(&#39;ask_language.html&#39;, {&#39;form&#39;: form, &#39;name&#39;:name})
<br/>        form = LanguageForm(input.GET)
<br/>        
<br/>        if form.is_valid():
<br/>            lang = form.cleaned_data[&#39;lang&#39;]
<br/>            if lang == &#39;python&#39;:
<br/>                yield Page(&quot;Cool, now refresh and see how much time you spent in this wizard&quot;)
<br/>            else:
<br/>                yield FinalPage(&quot;well %s, i guess you should look for a %s framework then...&quot; % (name,lang))
<br/>        else:
<br/>            yield FinalPage(&quot;hey, you are not going with the flow you know, goodbye %s.&quot; % name)
<br/>        
<br/>        delta = datetime.now() - started
<br/>        yield FinalPage(&quot;You spent %s seconds, bye %s !!&quot; % (delta.seconds, name))
<br/>Implementation facts:Stores generators in memory to achieve statefulness. Uses request.session.session_key to tell visitors apart. A different thread takes care of cleaning up &#39;old&#39; generators. Requires the server to run in a single process. (a better implementation could use a separate storage for &#39;living&#39; generators, or serializable tasklets like twisted&#39;s) Mostly experimental, yet small intranet applications could use it right away. Installation, requirements and usageQuick and dirtyJust checkout trunk, edit reelevant paths in settings.py and run: </p>

<p>python manage.py runserver :then play around with example_app/views.py </p>

<p>Long versionCheckout django_stateful Add the following to your settings.py (or use the one from the repository): SESSION_SAVE_EVERY_REQUEST = True #this forces session_keys even for anonymous users CLEAN_STATES_SECONDS = 60 #this checks every 60 seconds if any stored state is over 60 seconds old, thus the oldest a state can be is around 60*2 seconds import the following things:  from django_stateful.views import StatefulView, Page, FinalPage, show_page  
<br/>Define a class that would be your view, inheriting from StatefulView and redefine its &#39;main&#39; method Inside the &#39;main&#39; method: If you want to show a page to the user, you can yield a Page (which is no more than a clean subclass of HttpResponse), like this:  yield Page(&quot;here&#39;s something the server wants to say&quot;)  
<br/>If you want to render a template to the user, use &#39;show page&#39;, its just an alias for render_to_response, like this:  yield show_page(&#39;template.html&#39;, {&#39;foo&#39;: foo, &#39;bar&#39;:bar})  
<br/>Apart from yielding an HttpResponse, every yield statement recieves the request, args and kwargs from the url dispatching mechanism, so in cases where you want to use those (for instance, when showing a form and waiting for the user to submit it), you can use the following idiom:  input, args, kwargs = yield show_page(&#39;ask_for_input.html&#39;, {&#39;form&#39;: form})  
<br/>When you&#39;re done with coding your view, you import it from your urls.py file then set your class &#39;handle&#39; classmethod as the target for the dispatching mechanism, like this: from django.conf.urls.defaults import *
<br/>from my_project.views import MyCustomView</p>

<p>urlpatterns = patterns(&#39;&#39;,
<br/>    url(r&#39;^my_custom_view/$&#39;, MyCustomView.handle),
<br/>)</p>

 title : The django-watermark Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project provides a simple way for you to apply custom watermarks to images on your Django-powered website. </p>

<p>FeaturesOpacity: the filter allows you to specify the transparency level for your watermark image Watermark positioning: you have several options for positioning watermarks on your images Absolute: you can specify exact pixel locations for your watermark Relative: you can use percentages to place your watermark Corners: you can position your watermark in the corners of your images Random: you can tell the filter to randomly generate a position for your watermark Center: you can place watermarks in the center of the target image Scaling: the watermark can be scaled to cover your images or specify a scaling factor to use Tiling: the watermark can be tiled across your images Greyscale: you can convert the watermark to be greyscale before having it applied to the target image. Rotation: you can rotate your watermark a certain number of degrees or have the rotation be random. CreditsI snagged the original watermarking code from http://code.activestate.com/recipes/362879/ and turned it into a Django pluggable application.  Props to Shane Hathaway. </p>

<p>Requirementsdjango-watermark requires a modern version of the Django framework.  By modern I simply mean a version with the newforms-admin functionality.  If you&#39;re running on Django 1.0 or later, you&#39;re good. </p>

<p>django-watermark also relies upon the built-in django.contrib.admin and the Python Imaging Library (PIL).  I built it using PIL 1.1.6, but it may work with previous versions. </p>

<p>InstallationDownload django-watermark using one of the following methods: </p>

<p>easy_installYou can download the package from the CheeseShop or use </p>

<p>easy_install django-watermarkto download and install django-watermark. </p>

<p>Package DownloadDownload the latest .tar.gz, .tar.bz2, or .zip file from the downloads section and extract it somewhere you&#39;ll remember.  Use python setup.py install to install it. </p>

<p>Checkout from SubversionExecute the following command (or use the equivalent function in a GUI such as TortoiseSVN), and make sure you&#39;re checking Pendulum out somewhere on the PYTHONPATH. </p>

<p>svn co http://django-watermark.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/watermarker watermarkerVerifying InstallationThe easiest way to ensure that you have successfully installed Pendulum is to execute a command such as: </p>

<p>python -c &quot;import watermarker; print watermarker.get_version()&quot;If that displays the version of django-watermark that you tried to install, you&#39;re good to roll.  If you see something other than that, you probably need to check your PYTHONPATH environment variable. </p>

<p>ConfigurationFirst of all, you must add this project to your list of INSTALLED_APPS in settings.py: </p>

<p>INSTALLED_APPS = (
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.admin&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.auth&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.contenttypes&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sessions&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sites&#39;,
<br/>    ...
<br/>    &#39;watermarker&#39;,
<br/>    ...
<br/>)Run manage.py syncdb.  This creates the tables in your database that are necessary for operation. </p>

<p>While we&#39;re in this section, I might as well mention a settings variable that you can override: WATERMARKING_QUALITY.  This should be an integer between 0 and 100.  The default is 85. </p>

<p>UsageAs mentioned above, you have several options when using django-watermark.  The first thing you must do is load the filter for the template in which you wish to apply watermarks to your images. </p>

<p>{% load watermark %}From the Django admin, go ahead and populate your database with some watermarks that you want to apply to your regular images.  Simply specify a name for the watermark and upload the watermark image itself.  It&#39;s probably not a good idea to put commas in your watermark names.  Watermarks should be transparent PNG files for best results.  I can&#39;t make any guarantees that other formats will work nicely. </p>

<p>The first parameter to the watermark filter must be the name you specified for the watermark in the Django admin.  You can then choose from a few other parameters to customize the application of the watermark.  Here they are: </p>

<p>positionThis one is quite customizable.  First, you can plug your watermark into one corner of your images by using one of BR, BL, TR, and TL.  These represent &#39;bottom-right&#39;, &#39;bottom-left&#39;, &#39;top-right&#39;, and &#39;top-left&#39; respectively. </p>

<p>Alternatively, you can use relative or absolute positioning for the watermark.  Relative positioning uses percentages; absolute positioning uses exact pixels.  You can mix and match these two modes of positioning, but you cannot mix and match relative/absolute with the corner positioning.  When using relative/absolute positioning, the value for the position parameter is XxY, where X is the left value and Y is the top value.  The left and top values must be separated with a lowercase x. </p>

<p>If you wanted your watermark image to show up in the center of any image you want to watermark, you would use a position parameter such as position=50%x50% or even position=C.  If you wanted the watermark to show up half-way between the left and right edges of the image and 100 pixels from the top, you would use a position parameter such as position=50%x100. </p>

<p>Finally, you may tell the filter to generate a position for your watermark dynamically.  To do this, use position=R. </p>

<p>opacityThis parameter allows you to specify the transparency of the applied watermark.  The value must be an integer between 0 and 100, where 0 is fully transparent and 100 is fully opaque.  By default, the opacity is set at 50%. </p>

<p>tileIf you want your watermark to tile across the entire image, you simply specify a parameter such as tile=1. </p>

<p>scaleIf you&#39;d like to have the watermark as big as possible on the target image and fully visible, you might want to use scale=F.  If you want to specify a particular scaling factor, just use something like scale=1.43. </p>

<p>greyscaleIf you want your watermark to be greyscale, you can specify the parameter greyscale=1 and all color saturation will go away. </p>

<p>rotationSet this parameter to any integer between 0 and 359 (really any integer should work, but for your own sanity I recommend keeping the value between 0 and 359).  If you want the rotation to be random, use rotation=R instead of an integer. </p>

<p>Examples{{ image_url|watermark:&quot;My Watermark,position=br,opacity=35&quot; }}Looks for a watermark named &quot;My Watermark&quot;, place it in the bottom-right corner of the target image, using a 35% transparency level. </p>

<p>{{ image_url|watermark:&quot;Your Watermark,position=tl,opacity=75&quot; }}Looks for a watermark named &quot;Your Watermark&quot;, place it in the top-left corner of the target image, using a 75% transparency level. </p>

<p>{{ image_url|watermark:&quot;The Watermark,position=43%x80%,opacity=40&quot; }}Looks for a watermark named &quot;The Watermark&quot;, places it at 43% on the x-axis and 80% of the y-axis of the target image, at a transparency level of 40%. </p>

<p>{{ image_url|watermark:&quot;The Watermark,position=R,opacity=10,rotation=45&quot; }}Looks for a watermark named &quot;The Watermark&quot;, randomly generates a position for it, at a transparency level of 10%, rotated 45 degrees. </p>

<p>{{ image_url|watermark:&quot;w00t,opacity=40,tile=1&quot; }}Looks for a watermark called &quot;w00t&quot;, tiles it across the entire target image, at a transparency level of 40%.</p>
 title : The django-webcontrols Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django-webcontrols is a Django app that provides a Page object model.  The goal is to provide a lightweight framework that allows for the creation of reusable UI components with a focus on controls that make use of data sets.  The behavior and output of each control should be equally accessible from both the designer&#39;s and developer&#39;s perspective.</p>

 title : The django-widgets Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Create a widgets.py in your application. There you will create a class that subclasses Widget. </p>

<p>example: </p>

<p>class Login(Widget):
<br/>    template = &quot;account/login.html&quot;
<br/>    def get_context():
<br/>        return {&quot;login_form&quot;:LoginForm()} the widget has access to the request and the user. In the template you can do the following now: </p>

<p>{% load widget %}</p>

<p>{% widget Login %}This will render the template with the context from the get_context function. Widgets will be auto discovered. </p>

<p>Code is in alpha stage and not even tested in a production. commits follow... patches are welcome</p>
 summary : <p>A simple application for Django that provides a model and tags to manage and render YUI menus.</p>
 title : The django-yuimenu Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The example-django-app Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Project ideally for Django beginners. </p>

<p>Written in simple readable way, easily deployable on AlwaysData free hosting packet. </p>

<p>Currently upped @ http://klinika.alwaysdata.net </p>
