API בסיסיות של ה לפרויקט שלכם. התסריט הזה צריך לתמוך ב build.xml בשם Ant script משימה ד: לכתוב ● הבאים: targets לבנות (לקמפל + פעולות אחרות ע&quot;פ הצורך) את הפרויקט מתוך קוד המקור – build○ ואז להריץ את טסטים build לבצע – test○ שכוללת את כל מה שמשתמש צריך בכדי לקמפל את הקוד על המחשב zip ליצור – zipsrc○ עצמו) Ant script שלו (כולל האפשרות להריץ את ה שכוללת את כל מה שמשתמש צריך בכדי להריץ את הקוד על המחשב zip ליצור – zipbin○ שיריצו את תכנית ה run.sh- ו run.bat צריך לכלול שני תסריטים קצרים בשם zip שלו. ה Demo קודמים targets למחוק תוצרים של הרצת – clean○</p>
 title : The agent-sherpa Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Abstract. The year is 2010. It is another boiling hot day somewhere in the outskirts of Tikrit. A modified UN Personnel carrier pulls up at a dusty crossroads. The rear gate drops to form an exit ramp, but no soldiers emerge. Instead a swarm of dozens of miniature drone vehicles roll from the truck and set about their work. Using GPS they negotiate the local road network, their job to scan and and clear the roadside of IEDs (Improvised Explosive Devices). They reason whether or not a device is an IED using data from different perceptors and use actuators to handle the device in various ways. A centralised Command &amp; Control unit monitors the drones and predicts locations of other IED&#39;s or &quot;hotspots&quot; of enemy activity. The road is rendered safe for the UN convoy delivering emergency aid to the beleaguered city ahead.</p>

Demonstrate control of a character using either keyboard/mouse or any other appropriate controller. Demonstrate appropriate camera control in order to frame gameplay. Demonstrate an appropriate use of software engineering practice. </p>

<p>Appropriate use of advanced shadowing and lighting models. Appropriate use of particles and other visual effects. Demonstration of an advanced use of a particular middleware. Appropriate use of an Advanced AI technique. Networking functionality. Use of multiprocessing. </p>

 title : The air-war Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Air War is a turn-based strategy game of modern air warfare.  It features two sides, Red and Blue.  The red side has targets and air defense units with which to protect those targets.  The blue side has air units that seek to destroy the targets.  Red wins the game by exhausting all of blue&#39;s resources before all targets are destroyed.  Blue wins the game by destroying all red targets.  The game is turn-based in that red and blue set up the conditions for each mission before each turn is fought in a mission simulator.  The mission simulator determines the outcome of each mission in terms of targets and resources destroyed.  This repeats until the game is won.</p>
 title : The antos Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Name Changed to YAOS (Yet Another Operating System). </p>

<p>YAOS is an operating system written for x86 architecture.This OS is completely written in C and Assembly languages.This Operating System does not aim at having POSIX compliance and is written mainly for learning purpose and is also usable.This OS is for advanced users who have knowledge of what they are doing There are device drivers available for soft wares to access hardware however it may also access the hardware directly. </p>

<p>Goals A 32 bit OS which is usable The OS is written completely in C and Assembly Supports all the features provided by mainstream OS&#39;s Reduces the Bugs that are present OS&#39;s </p>

<p>This is how the OS Runs.The Operating System runs in Ring 0.The Drivers access the Hardware and all the user programs and applications run in Ring 3.The Softwares can not directly access the hardware they use only software interrupts and Drivers.This OS is mainly written to support preemptive multitasking and all processes run as thread and are executed based on their priorities. </p>

<p>Till Now the Kernel has
<br/># String and Memory Functions 
<br/># Text Display Functions 
<br/># GDT setup 
<br/># IDT setup 
<br/># Paging setup 
<br/># Dynamic Memory Allocation 
<br/># Timer 
<br/># Keyboard Irq 
<br/># Beep Functions 
<br/># C Shell
<br/># A Basic File System(Incomplete !!)
<br/># Few Shell Commands
<br/># Multi TaskingTo DO
<br/># Floppy Driver
<br/># Hard Disk Driver
<br/># DMA Controller
<br/># File System
<br/># Program Execution
<br/># List grows on.Post your comments here. </p>

<p>Status - Project Temporarily on Hold.</p>
 summary : <p>A suite of personal software on web or RIA., </p>
 title : The anysuites Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>OverviewThe Ascent Design Studio is a collection of algorithms/frameworks for the deployment and configuration of distributed, real-time, and embedded systems. ASCENT contains frameworks for: </p>

<p>Automated deployment planning with real-time scheduling, co-location constraints,   resource constraints, and network topology/resource constraints Deployment optimization algorithms An implementation of a self-healing/self-configuration framework for applications   built with the Java Spring framework  Constraint Satisfaction Problem (CSP) based automated feature model configurators An implementation of the Filtered Cartesian Flattening (FCF) algorithm for algorithmically selecting valid feature sets from feature models that adhere to resource constraints ASCENT includes an implementation of the Configuration ExploratioN Technique (ASCENT). The ASCENT algorithm takes one or more models of the hardware and software variability in a system and can solve for an optimal design configuration. The optimization goal is configurable. Ascent also produces a graph of the key trends in the solution space that can be used to perform a number of resource-based design analyses, such as finding the minimum cost to produce a solution with a given value. Getting StartedNew users should start by looking at the wiki pages for the features they are interested in: Go to the wiki.</p>
 title : The ascent-design-studio Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The ases Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Abstract Submission and Evaluation System, </p>
 summary : <p>ASP VBScript CMS is a pure Classic ASP web application targeted to small businesses needing a quick and easy Content Management System.  It is built with a modular approach to XHTML + CSS framework in mind. </p>

<p>CMS Features: </p>

<p>easy to use WYSIWYG editor (Dojo) page version control multi-lingual sites XHTML standards compliant html code generation Modular CSS Framework included (great for Designers looking for quick turnaround!) Ability to upload and manage files (File Upload Manager) Search engine friendly, human-readeable URLs based on actual file system page paths (ex, domain.com/path/to/page-name.asp instead of domain.com/Article.asp?id=23) framework for extending functionality (aka, modules / plugins) automatic generation of weighted Google xml sitemap a hand full of fully integrated modules simple product display and organization (no ecommerce gateways at this point) rss feed aggregator an extensible form creation module lytebox gallery module html snippets module random content module rotating banner module ability to easily re-brand the CMS for your company complete with sitewide global variables including: branded cms logo image path branded cms product name  producer name (your company&#39;s name) producer support email / contact email branded cms favicon seamlessly switch between localhost development configuration and production server without changing any config files. quick and easy Installation and setup for new projects. </p>

<p>Common CMS features that have been left out: </p>

<p>Blogs. Although its quite possible for someone to contribute a module for blogging, there&#39;s already so many blog solutions out there, we haven&#39;t bothered to reinvent the wheel for this CMS. We&#39;ve stuck to the concept of &quot;pages&quot;.  You may &quot;aggregate&quot; your external blog entries into a page on your site via the RSS aggregation module. Technical Details: </p>

<p>Classic ASP 3.0 VBScript + very small pieces written in server-side ASP JScript MS Access (.mdb) database format Tested on IIS 5.0 localhost (standard with Windows XP) Tested on IIS 6.0 production server (standard at most Windows-based web hosting environments) Project Dependencies: </p>

<p>Dojo Toolkit (via AOL CDN) Tango Icon Theme (embedded) Documentation and Testing: </p>

<p>code comment coverage hasn&#39;t been measured but some documentation does exist for parts of the code that could easily be reused in other projects. An attempt has been made to conform and update to a doxygen format compatible with ASP syntactical comments.   test coverage hasn&#39;t been measured but some hand-made tests were done and included in the development branch. There is no general purpose testing framework (unit or otherwise) that I know of for ASP :/ Questions / Comments </p>

<p>asp.vbscript.cms  (at) G.m.A.i.L  (lowercase without the dots)  PERIOD (com)</p>

 title : The axedarea Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>AxedArea is an editor widget written with the Google Web Toolkit, which isn&#39;t just a TextArea but also does not depend on browser specifc propertery builtin edit-extentions.  </p>

<p>In AxedArea everything is coded in GWT as far as the caret actually is a html div element. This allows an axedarea to be a lot more customized than an any editor using browser internal editor extentions. AxedArea is thus also W3C compatible!  </p>

<p>Release 1.2 is available! </p>

<p>View it: </p>

<p>You can view an Online Demo as used in an example gwt-project You can also view an Online JSNI-Demo or vimish Demo for use from plain javascript (look at the sourcecode of the html pages) </p>

<p>ChangeLog 1-2: </p>

<p>The core has been greatly changed. Many, many stones are now on different places.  Most notably changed the internals from int-arrays and offset pointing to an object-lists model. HtmlString handling is now thus quite simplified. This is in preparation to add new &quot;enriching&quot; elements like ranges targeted for version 1.3. There hardly should be any noticeable changes on the user-interface to 1.1. The editing performance should be vastly improved.  (Note: pasting huge blocks might however be worse right now, since there isn&#39;t just  yet a &quot;paste lazy calculation accelerator&quot; available for the new core.) </p>

<p>Also See:  </p>

<p>Documentation </p>

<p>License: </p>

<p>Axedarea is alternatively available with Apache License 2.0 or GPLv2 or any later GPL version. So licensing should hardly be an issue for anyone. </p>

<p>For feedback please message me: axel77 (at) gmail.com</p>

 title : The bioview2 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Please be patient as I am doing this in my spare timeBioView was originally devised as a subcomponent of the AutoCSA project (CGP - Sanger Institute).  The initial version only contains the Chromatogram rendering code for visulisation of sequencing data.  The main driving force of this was that the existing BioJava code was heavily biased towards processed data and was inefficient when rendering sub sections of chromatograms. </p>

<p>The intended future of BioView is to provide further easy to use components such as exon and chromosome mapping and visualisation tools. </p>

 title : The carom Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Carom is a classical physics engine, written in C++, with many important features. It provides machine-independent, arbitrary-precision results (through use of the MPFR library), compile-time unit-correctness checking, mesh-based collision detection and response, and uses the RK4 numerical algorithm. </p>

<p>For an overview of the Carom library, see Design.</p>
 title : The cjwizard Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CJWizard is an API for creating wizard dialogs in Java. </p>

<p>This library was spurred by my use of the Java Wizard library at Java.net (https://wizard.dev.java.net/).  That library offers a good framework for simple wizards, but it dictates a great deal of what you can do--justified by the java usability guidelines.  However, I don&#39;t believe all the restrictions actually are justified by those guidelines.  For example, it is particularly difficult to change the type of widget used on the left side of the wizards (it is initially an image with the list of wizard pages displayed over top of it).  Making this area interactive, as a global navigation tool, is non-trivial. </p>

<p>I also found it to be extremely cumbersome to define complex wizards that change their branching behavior at runtime.  Generally, I found the Java Wizard API to be difficult to use and at times contradictory.   </p>

<p>That said, I learned a lot from the Java Wizard API, and some of those ideas have been incorporated into CJWizards (which stands for Ciscavate Java Wizards, or something like that.  I had to call it something.) </p>

<p>Take a look at the FAQ and QuickStartGuide to get going, and send me questions if you have any. </p>

<p>ScreenshotsThis shows CJWizard in action, with a custom PageTemplate (drawing the list of dialog pages on the left) that wraps around a TitledPageTemplate (drawing the underlined title of the WizardPage).  The Windows L&amp;F was used to make it look like a native app.  (The Finish button is enabled because the surrounding app is robust to missing data, and allows for the user to come back to the wizard at a later date, if needed.  Generally, and by default, the Finish button is disabled if it is not explicitly enabled, which often happens in the render() method of the last WizardPage)</p>

 title : The crudgenerator Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CRUD GeneratorCRUDGenerator automatizes repetitive tasks in generating forms to create, read, update and delete data (aka CRUD). Beginning from an hibernate bean (the model), the controller and the views (with a custom taglib) are automatically created. The Spring Inversion of Control bind the three MVC layers. </p>

<p>See CRUD Generator in action! Click here for a demo </p>

<p>Development StatusAlpha Intended AudienceDevelopers EnvironmentConsole (Text Based). Eclipse plugin planned. Programming LanguageJava Operating SystemOS Independent TopicSoftware Development: Code Generators       </p>

<p>                                                                 </p>

<p>News10/04/08  Project suspended due to the start of a new one. If you are looking for a good CRUDGenerator take a look at JBoss Seam and its generator. 30/06/07  Project split: CRUDGenerator (the core classes), CtrlTagLib (the taglib used by CRUDGenerator), KostiaUtil (common utilities) and CRUDGenDemo (a demo webapp). 20/06/07  Closes issued 1 and 10 (Coherent date format and discard changes on close) 04/06/07  Released input suggest jsp tag. 31/05/07  Modified the code to respect the o-o metrics in eclipse plugin Metrics in order to guarantee manutenibily and readiness. Read some object oriented coding best practice in the Wiki. 30/05/07  Added tables PROJECTS and EMPLOYEES_PROJECTS (link table) to create many-to-many relationship with EMPLOYEES 27/05/07  Migrate database from Oracle to Apache Derby (lighter and faster)</p>

 title : The descent-deep-assault Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Descent: Deep AssaultDescent: Deep Assault (possibly to be called Full Metal Drive) is an original game being developed alongside the Mocha Game Library, which is now hosted on Launchpad. It is partly inspired by the original Descent series of games (hence the name), but is original. The namesake is really an homage. </p>

<p>Descent is a top-down shooter wherein the player takes control of a hovercraft-like fighter. One of the story concepts includes the use of a full metal drive, the primary power source of the futuristic setting. The player maneuvers the fighter through deep space mines collecting fuel (so-called full metal) while destroying killer robots and carefully avoiding collisions and loss of control. </p>

<p>Planning and MigratingThe project is in a very preliminary state, especially while the Mocha Game Library transitions to Launchpad where it will (hopefully) mature. It will also be migrated to Launchpad once code is ready to be committed. This page will still be maintained, mostly for the wiki pages. Source code and issues will not be tracked here.</p>
 title : The descomp Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A comprehensive library for supporting various design computation functions </p>

<p>-- </p>

<p>Design computation has been a rapidly evolving field both in terms of engineering as well as architecture or in other words primarily geometrical. It covers a very well connected set of topics including shape representation and generation, parametric and generative algorithms which themselves depend on a parametric framework, digital modeling, simulation and geometrical analysis of form and shape grammar. </p>

<p>In spite of the large amount of literature and academic research on the same, there exists no open source or commercial application framework for performing these computations. In particular even though there is some activity going on in the field of form generation, there is hardly any common platform for implementation of various algorithms (genetic, evolutionary and otherwise) and generative methods of planning, layout etc dealing with the more rigorous parts of form generation. Also it is surprising that there exists no good system for major theories/ techniques such as Shape grammar or Pattern Language. Even critical necessities such as parametric geometry, pattern generation, are supported by no open source CAD application. The aim of the project is the implementation of a design computation library (DCL) which would enable researchers to deal with mathematical and computational aspects of design more easily, significantly reducing the reinvention of the wheel. The range of implementation is mostly in the realm of rigorous space planning, parametric and generative geometry, and shape grammar.</p>

 summary : <p>This code base contains example implementations of various design patterns., </p>
 title : The design-patterns-code-base Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The design-scripting-library Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>IntroductionDesign Scripting is a &quot;Visual Basic Scripting&quot; library suited for design purposes, namely CAD systems and 3D geometry. It contains a variety of vertex/vector functions but extends to more generic functionality such as file reading/writing etc. DSLib is a prototyping package for rapidly hacking and testing ideas before potentially hard coding design processes in more advanced languages. You can hack up from simple straight forward automation scripts to abstract generative processes without getting into the compile/debug world of computing or the painful world of pure macro command sequencing. </p>

<p>HistoryI begun writing DSLib while I was studying in MIT back in 2003. It was developed for general purpose scripting with a special focus on geometry. I have been using dslib mainly from within the Rhinoceros CAD environment, yet I tried to keep it free from a specific hosting application. Notice: as of version 2.0 some functionality that is Rhino specific has been added yet without creating dependencies. </p>

<p>PhilosophyScripting is an easy access point to computation that avoids the over-generalization syndrome of its underlying science but yet provides the facilities for expressive design experimentations. The Design Scripting Library was build in this gradual ad-hoc-ish mode in a necessity basis a.k.a. patchwork. It follows a multi paradigm approach borrowing concepts and functionality from both low level computer languages (see the c-flavored polymorphic sort for instance) and high level languages (see php-like echo function for another). </p>

<p>ParticipationI can no longer maintain DSLib by myself. If you are interested in writing new methods, correcting bugs, bettering the documentation send me a note. Contributions will be properly acknowledged.  </p>

<p>StructureThe library comes in two components: a pure set of scripting functions and an extension dynamic link library that overcomes the limitations of the programming language. The library is structured in contextual blocks (pseudo-namespaces) and I tried to enforce an object-oriented feel into the procedural nature of Basic. Most of the code is self-explanatory.  </p>

<p>Scripting is by nature slower than proper programming, therefore I decided to keep the code thin without any error checks etc. Performance sacrifices were made but only in terms of modularization and encapsulation.  </p>

<p>Loading and UsingDSLib is doing nothing by itself (this is a common question). You need to write some code that uses it. In version 1.0 all you need to do in order to start working with the library is to load it before your code. This can be done in a number of ways:  </p>

<p>Load it through your CAD GUI into the scripting engine  Load it in your application via a Scripting Control Control Load it internally from your script by reading the file in a string and globalexecute it As of version 2.0 the single file monolith was broken down into multiple files. This makes maintenance much easier. The process of loading the library is a bit different! You need to either: </p>

<p>Load all files using one of the previous methods Load only the dslib.vb file and call the load function that takes care of all other files.</p>

 title : The dqug Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DQuG, Doug&#39;s Query enGine, is the name of both a functional, relational, and object-oriented database engine and the query language accepted by this database engine. DQuG is quite nearly a &#39;D&#39; language, in the sense of TheThirdManifesto, with a few reasoned exceptions. </p>

<p>DQuG is designed to support existing and emerging database applications by supporting reliable, secure, extensible, and simple storage and flexible retrieval of all types of information.</p>

 title : The editable-framework-js Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The built in rich text editing in web browsers is implemented badly and restricts the ability of web developers to produce functional applications. </p>

<p>This project will build a framework for creating document editors, from which can be built WYSIWYG, semantic and XML editors. </p>

<p>It will use DOM manipulation only to be completely compatible with past and future versions of all the mainstream browsers. </p>

<p>See a proof-of-concept demo here: http://www.fluffy.co.uk/stediting/ </p>

<p>DocumentationMotivation -- why this project exists </p>

<p>UseCases -- what you&#39;d use it for </p>

<p>Challenges -- the difficulties of writing an editor in Javascript </p>

<p>API -- proposed API for the framework </p>

<p>Design -- design document for how it&#39;ll work </p>

<p>NotesOnProofOfConcept -- notes on how the proof-of-concept works</p>

<p>Final Report Template PostedI have briefly created a template for our final report.  I&#39;ve attached both the 2007 version and 2003 version.  I have also attached one of the sample reports provided.   IMPORTANT:   In the Software Architecture Portion of the report:   Diagrams must be created - Please use the Attached ExampleReport2.pdf as a reference guide on how our diagrams and flow charts should look like. (Roger - you are the software architect, so the main class/engine flow diagrams should be your responsibility)   Detailed Module Structure Portion:   Please refer to the UML and flow chart diagrams used in the attached ExampleReport2.pdf.  I expect the same from everyone - Ideally, there should be a chart for each class, but some can be integrated into others.   Feature Descriptions Portion:   Each Feature description should follow this template: Rationale -1 Paragraph on the purpose of the feature. -1 Paragraph on why you did what you did in Brackets like this. Implementation -Paragraph(s) briefly describing how you implemented this feature and the process in which you came to the final implementation (describe failed attempts at additional features).   Outcome 1 paragraph to summarize the final Achievements and Failures (To show effort on advanced features). If you guys have any other questions, we can discuss it on Saturday at Lance&#39;s.  Also refer to the attached ExampleReport if you need examples.   BR,   Adrian </p>

 title : The eel4884jc Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Extended Environments Markup Language (EEML, http://www.eeml.org/), is a protocol for sharing sensor data between remote responsive environments, both physical and virtual. It can be used to facilitate direct connections between any two environments; it can also be used to facilitate many-to-many connections as implemented by the web service Pachube (http://www.pachube.com/), which enables people to tag and share real time sensor data from objects, devices and spaces around the world. </p>

<p>This code is for the EEML library for Processing (http://www.processing.org/), as outlined here: http://www.eeml.org/library/ </p>

<p>To use with Java, until the code has been refactored, you just need to import the relevant classes and jars as outlined here: http://community.pachube.com/?q=node/113#comment-141</p>

 title : The esmi Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Welcome to the Eclipse Scala Maven Integration. We aim to provide better support to both Q for eclipse (soon to be IAM) and the Scala Eclipse plugin, as well as integrating them together. This project is purposefully narrow in scope. This allows us (me) to focus our efforts and be able to maintain this integration. Ideals </p>

<p>The goals/ideals of this project are as follows: </p>

<p>Use existing plugins to the greatest extent possible Use Maven for our build system Use Scala as our core language Meet needs as they arise in the Eclipse/Scala/Maven world Support projects like Lift, which make use of Scala and Maven. Enjoy what we do Become a one-stop-shop for eclipse users who want Scala and Maven tools.  Note that this project houses not only the eclipse-maven-scala integration but also the integration between Scala and Maven.  Information on the Scala and Maven integration can be found at ScalaMavenSupport with a task list available at ScalaMavenSupportTaskList  </p>

<p>StatusThis project is temporarily on hold </p>

<p>For the meantime please follow the CreatingScalaMavenProjectsInEclipse wiki article to start using Scala and Maven together. </p>

<p>Pre ReleaseThere is an pre-pre-pre alpha available at the update site: http://esmi.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/update_site_dev/. This requires you to already have the old, unreleased beta version of the Scala Eclipse plugin (at least the scala-library portion).   This should be updated in the coming weeks for scala 2.7.3 </p>

<p>Immediate Goals:Build System (Maven) Update-Site wiring (We should reference Scala and Q update sites from our own) Project Import/Creation integration between Q and Scala  Future Goals:m2e integration use scala:cc task for contious compilation Automated testing of esmi Continuous Integration of esmi Clean Scala SDT-RCP interface sbaz -&gt; maven dependency</p>
 summary : <p>Welcome to DEXEN, a design exploration system that uses evolutionary techniques to evolve and adapt designs to meet a set of design objectives. The key characteristics of DEXEN are as follows: </p>

<p>It is implemented in Python, and is currently Windows only (Macs and Linux to be added soon). It has been tested on XP and Vista. This current version has no graphical user interface. It is a system that requires the user to write a set of Python scripts that define the key evolutionary steps. These scripts will be executed by the system in order to run the evolutionary process. It is very flexible since the scripts can be used to implement a wide variety of evolutionary algorithms. In addition, these scripts can also be used as a way of linking to other software, such as CAD applications and simulation programs. It is reasonably fast since the system can be run on multiple computers in parallel. The architecture allows client computers to be easily added and removed from the evolutionary process.</p>

 summary : <p>This is a one stop, free, open source shoutbox system developed in PHP using the GD library to render a shoutbox as an image. The primary use if for forum signatures so people can leave their mark, but it can be used wherever you can use an image. </p>

 title : The geagle Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>GoalThe goal of this project is to summarize the function of each gene using four keywords. The source of information to find which words will be used is mainly &#39;geneRif&#39; (ftp://ftp.ncbi.nih.gov/gene/GeneRIF/generifs_basic.gz).  title : The geotagger Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Geotagging is a method of adding GPS data to the EXIF header of photographs (found in JPEG and other file formats). </p>

<p>Geotagger is a tool to help geotag photos.  This can be done manually by locating a spot on a map or automatically by correlating with data from a GPS. </p>

<p>Geotagger is written in C# and uses Google Maps in an embedded web browser for visualizing the GPS data and photo locations.   </p>

<p>This tool is meant to do only one thing - Geotag photos.  It will not create KML files, it will not create GPX files, it will not resize photos, it will not post photos to web sites.  It will just write GPS data into EXIF headers of photographs. </p>

<p>This is a work in progress and is not yet complete.  Please read the wiki or http://notions.okuda.ca/geotagger/ for updates.</p>

 summary : <p>The GitTorrent Protocol (GTP) is a protocol for collaborative git repository distribution across the Internet. </p>

<p>It might currently come across as a solution looking for a problem - and as one smart-ass with admin rights to the Google Code project reminds you on the source tab, &quot;more alpha than the greek letter&quot;.  The initial motivation was performance of downloads and in particular reducing load on kernel.org. </p>

<p>That&#39;s one reason d&#39;etre, but to those who argue that is insufficient justification for its existence, that Git is already fast enough - it is a first step towards applying decentralizing Peer to Peer concepts to Git.  If you decentralize the download layer, it&#39;s just another small step before you decentralize the push rights and tie it to a web of trust such as PGP, and then you don&#39;t actually need discrete mirror sites.  Every mirror can track the git repositories the owners want it to carry, and those authorized to sign updates can make signed updates to push the cloud forward.  Your local mirror can become a one-stop git push and pull stop depot, and the source code is preserved in many more places, increasing resilience, availability and download performance for all. </p>

<p>These longer-term plans would have been included in the RFC, but for a desire to keep it simple and build the first layer first. </p>

<p>Status and HistoryLast status announcement was at August 2008.  That demonstrated a program which started two gittorrent daemons, which connect to each other over TCP and exchange a repository using the messages in the RFC. </p>

<p>So, initially, Jonas came up with the idea and made a thesis out of it.  Along the way it was I think mentioned on #git, and I (Sam) got involved, reviewed the design and came up with a design that did not require unnecessary extra indexes to be distributed among peers, while still making good use of delta compression.  ie, when pulling over a limited bandwidth connection there should be minimal extra downloaded compared to pulling from one server. </p>

<p>So, we&#39;ve been through 2 rounds of Google Summer of Code participation, and a small amount of time from me (Sam) in getting it this far.  Currently no-one is (to my knowledge) actively developing either this developed version (sorry, I don&#39;t get paid for this, it&#39;s really just when I have the time, inclination etc) or Jonas&#39; C++ implementation. </p>

<p>What&#39;s likely to happen next is that at the GitTogether, this will be explained and a simple path forward laid that will layer this technology over git&#39;s native protocol, and leave the BitTorrent baggage behind.  If there is sufficient interest, then the project may get another breath of life. </p>

<p>Welcome SlashdottersIt has been pointed out that there has been no update on what happened at GitTogether.  Basically, as the final paragraph in the above points out, it needs to work over the git:// protocol to be useful, and as it turns out the design of git makes this much simpler than I originally thought.  A proof of concept could in principle be thrown together as a single script loosely based on the existing Perl implementation, and a trivial patch to the git-daemon to enable it.  I&#39;ve put the sketch of this on this wiki using the name it will probably end up with - &quot;MirrorSync&quot; </p>

<p>Prototypes for the individual messages are still pending, but hopefully you can see that the design is now sufficiently simple that this shouldn&#39;t be an arduous task... take a look and please comment if you&#39;ve something to add!</p>
 title : The gittorrent Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The gle-mips Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Welcome to GLE-MiPS    </p>

<p>This site features a collection of different kind of processors, described in pure vhdl code. All started with a MIPS-like non pipelined cpu from which several branches spawned!  </p>

<p>Right now the following types of processor are available, but many more will be added in the future! </p>

<p>GLE-MiPS - A fully working microprocessor, featuring a complete set of mathematical and logical operations over integer numbers, with the addition of two memory modules, RAM and ROM; it is synthetizable both in 32 and in 64 bits mode. A crosscompiler is available, written in Java, 3k-cc. QUATTRO - A microprocessor for small embedded devices, with strict size and speed requirements! Uses 8 bit instructions for a 4 bit architecture. It&#39;s basically a shrinked down, 4 bit version of GLE-MiPS (spawned from version 1.1). GLX - A written from scratch processor, implementing a non pipelined DLX structure, with Very Long Instruction Word support, allowing parallel execution of two instructions. It doesn&#39;t have the mathematical capabilities of GLE-MiPS but has a revised logicals module and comparison capabilities. News07/08/2008 - QUATTRO 1.1 - Thanks to the knowledge acquired in the GLX development, a newer, faster version of QUATTRO is available! The new structure doesn&#39;t use the big GLE-MiPS macroblocks any more, but relies on small modules, achieving greater performance. </p>

<p>05/08/2008 - GLX 1.0 - Finally available, the DLX processor implementation with Very Long Instruction Word support. It comes with physical design reports, Synopsys scripts and the related cross-compiler. </p>

<p>28/07/2008 - GLX PREVIEW - Here is available for download a preview release of a DLX implementation! It&#39;s still not complete as it&#39;s lacking of the pipeline and several other features, but it&#39;s in a good shape for general testing. </p>

<p>25/07/2008 - 3k-cc BETA 1 - After a long time announcement, it is finally here! The compiler for the GLE-MiPS has just been released! It&#39;s still a beta as it still needs some testing, but it&#39;a bless for GLE-MiPS testers out there. </p>

<p>Older News </p>

<p>If you want to help, you are more than welcome! Drop me a mail if you are interested!</p>

 title : The golfml Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The purpose of GolfML is to provide a XML-based file format for the exchange of golf-related data. </p>

<p>There are numerous golf scorecard programs and online web sites that allow golfers to browse course information, print scorecards, keep track of scores, and analyze statistics, or view a Google Earth fly-over of each hole. </p>

<p>Most programs or web sites use proprietary data representation and only few of them allow for data exchange of course descriptions such as scorecard, hole par, length and handicap strokes. If available, data import or export is often performed in site- or application-specific proprietary format. </p>

<p>We promote the use of a vendor-neutral, open data format for the exchange of golf-related data like golf course descriptions, or golfer scorecards. </p>

<p>The markup language will focus on: </p>

<p>The description of golf courses The golfer&#39;s logbook, with scorecards and statistics The first part of this project defines a uniform data format to present golf course information such as name, address, number of courses, available facilities, course description, individual hole tee length, par, handicap strokes, etc. This data format also allows definition of geographic areas such as coordinates (of tees, holes, trees and traps...) or surfaces (such as fairways, bunkers, greens, lake...). It also permit references to files like pictures, video, or other media. </p>

<p>The second part of the project defines a data format to allow golfer to record scores, statistics, and golf equipment. Scores can be as simple as stroke counts or as complex as location-based individual stroke record. </p>

<p>This project will not deliver software code. It will deliver a vocabulary, XML specifications and references to allow for data exchange between golf software applications. </p>

<p>Start Here or look at Typical Uses of GolfML</p>
 summary : <p>Google users will use their Google account to access this new application.  This application will be available anywhere the user can get internet.  Google Classroom will be a content management system that students can use through their Google account.  The interface would be similar to other content management systems such as Angel, but is not University driven.  As a result, the users will be able to customize the system to fit their needs.   </p>

<p>The system will link with other Google applications, such as Google Docs, and Google Calendar, to increase usability.  Users will be able to add their courses to the system. Within each course, it will be possible to take notes, upload documents, manage due dates, and meeting times, etc.  The overall goal for this project will be to draw more users to the Google Corporation.  Google Classroom will appeal to the younger generation of users.  These users are mostly likely in high school and college.  Google Classroom will target this segment of the market.</p>

 summary : <p>This project provides a user interface to Hackystat data based upon the Simile/Timeline system.  </p>

<p>The goal is to provide a way to create a timeline in which each single time line represents developer activity using a type of tool.  For example, one time line could represent the use of the Eclipse tool over time, with various significant events (compile, etc.) noted along it.  Another time line could represent unit testing, another SVN commits, and so forth.  </p>

<p> 
<br/>The result provides insight into the patterns of development that occur, as well as gaps during development where nothing seems to be happening. Such &#39;Dead Time&#39; could be as interesting and important to the overall productivity and effectiveness of development as the periods of time where development is occuring.</p>

 title : The hawking-toolbar Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The Hawking Toolbar Project&#39;s goal is to design a firefox plugin which will enable users to navigate website links (and other clickable content) using a limited interface. This will allow users with disablilities to interact with a simple interface customized to best suit their abilities. This project hopes to achieve a plugin with two styles: </p>

<p>A basic, limited interface for specialized literacy teaching to disabled people A robust toolbar which will allow interfacing not only with the website, but also the browser history, (back, forward, refresh) The plugin should not recognize links  tags but also form buttons and any object on the page with javascript onClick event capturing. The selection of links should be easily recognizable and customizable to the abilities of the user </p>

 title : The herpnet Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>OverviewThe HerpNet project has funded the development of a DwC record cache at the University of California at Berkeley. In general, the cache stores records containing DwC concepts from a set of data providers. In particular, the cache: </p>

<p>Stores concepts from the DwC TAPIR application schema.  Supports data access using the TAPIR and DiGIR protocols. Sends query logs to each provider using the TAPIR protocol.  Provides a mechanism for synchronizing cached data with providers.   </p>

<p>ImplementationGoogle Web Toolkit, Apache Tomcat, Java 1.5, Hibernate, MySQL, Python.</p>

 summary : <p>About HTKOUHTKOU stands for &quot;Hutong Kou&quot; (胡同口), which is the entrance to a &quot;Hutong&quot; in which people live, laugh and share in harmony.  HTKOU Forum is a (yet another) PHP-based Internet forum system that is designed specifically for the Chinese community.  HTKOU Forum is intended to be an intuitive, simple, lean and yet powerful open-source forum system that people can download and build their own &quot;Hutongs&quot; however they want. </p>

<p>HTKOU Forum was formerly developed on a private server by the HTKOU team and v1.0 has been completed and deployed at http://www.htkou.net/.  title : The ignitionbase Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>IgnitionBase is built from ground-up with 5 major goals in mind: - Lightweight and Fast - Extensible and Scalable - Secure - Object-Oriented, Modular Structure - HMVC Based, able to regress to Controller-centric MVC </p>

<p>It is meant to be a rigorous exercise in lean engineering principles, combining a rock solid lightweight framework with a heavy and extensible supporting library. </p>

<p>It is meant to be community-driven, and aimed to cut down solution delivery time. </p>

<p>It is also meant to serve as a platform to encourage, educate and enable proper modular engineering patterns and processes.</p>

 title : The jaac Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The proposed solution is to create a proxy class (as provided by Java&#39;s reflection package) together with an annotated interface which indicates the appropriate &quot;undo&quot; for each method. This allows a class&#39; code to remain direct and uncluttered; the actions are generated at runtime and stored or undone by external handlers. </p>

<p>The problem is how to both use the command design pattern and retain the cohesion of directly implemented code. The command pattern promotes a method call to an object, improving program flexibility. The cost is source cohesion; either command code is injected into class, or the class&#39; behavior is extracted into command subclasses. </p>

<p>Two sample applications are implemented using the suggested solution: a min-max tic-tac-toe player and a backtracking sudoku solver, which extends the action class to provide transactions.</p>
 title : The jamun Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Jamun is a sweet dish that makes you say... Yum! </p>

<p>Jamun is not ready for prime time yet. </p>

<p>Watch this space for updates. (There&#39;s an update feed available too)</p>
 summary : <p>IntroductionAspect Oriented is a paradigm of development that grows day by day. Visualize how this aspects affect the whole application is a difficult matter of study. This project helps the software developer and architect to have the vision of how any AOP application is constructed and how each component interacts with each other. </p>

<p>ProblemWe need to identify and show how aspects interfere within the system model. </p>

<p>SolutionAt first we thought of a solution similar to how a compiler parses a portion of code, analyzes it grammatically and then generates a sense of code to be interpreted by a virtual machine or an operating system. In an analog way, in our solution we have to think about a source code program that has to be parsed to build a kind of basic and generic scene and finally this scene be shown in an specific visualizer.  </p>

<p>The sense of divide it in three components makes the solution more flexible, providing pluggable components in the parser or either in the adapter. That is, you can choose any parser if you give to the model builder what it needs and you can choose any visualizer if you build the adapter to show the scene. </p>

<p>ConclusionWe have investigated so far many possibilities to solve the cited problem discovering that in the field of AOP, AspectJ has become the widely-used de-facto standard by emphasizing simplicity and usability for end users. The lack of tools that can clearly show how the aspects crosscut the different model objects makes our approach an amazing challenge to help AOP developers to have a full comprehension of how the system is interacting. </p>

<p>How to configure the projectProject configuration and install</p>
 title : The jaspict3d Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The javava Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Background StoryOne day, I went home after work, and wanted to watch TV Play downloaded in my laptop, but...it seemed that something important needed to be done. So I wrote all the things on paper, what I should do first? and what was the last. </p>

<p>Tasks I need to do  Importance  Urgent Level   Call back to my mum for greeting  a little important(2)  a little urgent(2)   Cook for my wife  most important(5)  urgent(3)   Watch TV Play  not important(1)  not urgent(1)   Read one chapter of python  important(3)  urgent(3)   Fix a known bug in my product  very important(4)  very urgent(4)  </p>

<p>Compare all the tasks, what should I do first? Apparently, I have to cook for my wife at first, and then fix the known bug in my product, after that, I should read one chapter of python e-book, and then call back to my mum. At last, if I have enough time I can watch TV play for a season. </p>

<p>After organizing my tasks, the order is totally changed: </p>

<p>What I should do  Importance  Urgent Level   Cook for my wife  most important(5)  urgent(3)   Fix a known bug in my product  very important(4)  very urgent(4)   Read one chapter of python  important(3)  urgent(3)   Call back to my mum for greeting  a little important(2)  a little urgent(2)   Watch TV Play  not important(1)  not urgent(1)  </p>

<p>Life is meaningful if you organize yourself well. You may have thought about what is the most important thing in your life? my answer is - time, if money were gone, you could earn it again, but if your time flew, you could not get it back. Trust me, manage yourself well, you will be very successful. </p>

<p>Download JavavaTaskJavava Task - A small tool, which manages daily tasks for you, can sort your tasks by importance and urgent level. Actually it is very useful for me on my daily work, I could determine what I should do in every minute, so the efficiency of work is totally improved. </p>

<p>Download the latest javavatask-1.0.1. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>If you are interested in this project, please join in discussion group, or send email to jiakuan.</p>

 title : The jtextextract Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Allows developer to extract text from multiple format files such as MS-Office pre-2007 (Word, PPT, XLS), MS-Visio, MS-Office-2007 (docx, pptx,xlsx), PDF, RTF, XML, HTML, Text etc. </p>

<p>Usage scenarios: </p>

<p>1. Use this library to extract text from multiple format files such as MS-Office pre-2007 (Word, PPT, XLS), MS-Visio, MS-Office-2007 (docx, pptx,xlsx), PDF, RTF, XML, HTML, Text etc. and then pass the text to indexing engine such as Lucene for indexing and search across attachments later </p>

<p>2. Extract text from attachments in email </p>

<p>3. Use in any generic search engine that supports search in file attachments </p>

<p>It uses a number of complimentary libraries/technologies such as Apache POI, OpenXML4J and PDFBox.</p>
 summary : <p>A collection of graphing widgets designed to be integrated into KDE 4.This project was started due to the lack of standard graphing components in KDE.  As it is today, any developer wishing to incorporate graphing of date into their application must create the graph widget him/herself.  This leads to many different, poorly performing and unattractive graph widgets throughout KDE applications. </p>

<p>The goal of this project is to make graphing widgets which borrow from tricks devised by the computer game industry over the years to create high performance, beautiful graph widgets for a wide variety of uses.  The intent is to create everything from bar graphs to line graphs to cartesian coordinate graphs to speedometer-like analog meters.</p>

 summary : <p>Lingua Franca is a plug-in for chat clients which enable translation of chat messages to user configured language. </p>

<p>Below are the basic features </p>

<p>User can translate all the incoming chat text to language of his preference User can translate all outgoing chat messages to language of his choice User can translate outgoing chat text to a particular buddy from his list Any combination of 1,2,3 is possible (for ex he may have set 1 on 2 off and 3 on , etc) 
<br/>Note: language translation may have issues when words of one language are intersperse in another language So no guarantees that (1) , (2), (3) will be obeyed even if user mixes things.  
<br/>Best effort translation only.    Beta version of the source code is available now. </p>

<p>so enjoy , chat in the languages you wish to ! </p>

 summary : <p>There are plenty of tools that do specific functions, or a range of technical functions (NMAP, Nessus). However, there are not many open source tools to help manage the scope of the testing a system. Lockpick will fill that role. For intelligence gathering, Lockpick will let me create profiles for target companies and persons. I can shell out to my normal tool suite and organize my log files and other output with the tool. Eventually, I can use Lockpick to pull all of the testing data together and generate an executive summary and detail report with the logs and profiles for addenda.</p>

 title : The longhouse Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Introduction to LonghouseThis project page represents the Longhouse project, begun by Informatics students at the University of California, Irvine, in conjunction with representatives of Google Code.  </p>

<p>Longhouse is an open-source collaborative development environment (CDE) based on Google Code. Longhouse provides software project hosting, issue tracking, and a space for collaborative work on software projects. Unlike Google Code, Longhouse is intended for small- to medium-sized organizations or communities that wish to host their own software projects. Thus, Longhouse may be installed on a modern personal computer or small- to medium-sized server to serve your organization&#39;s project hosting and management needs.  </p>

<p>Longhouse employs a unique means of storing project data and making data accessible, storing information in XML format on your organization&#39;s Subversion repository. This means that you can edit any project artifacts outside the Longhouse Web UI, commit the modified XML files to your Subversion repository, and have Longhouse automatically take into account your changes.  </p>

<p>Longhouse aims to preserve the usability paradigms of Google applications while adding additional usability optimizations designed to maximize understandability, new-user-friendliness and productivity. </p>

<p>We invite you to learn more about Longhouse, and to get Longhouse. </p>

<p>See what&#39;s going on with Longhouse. </p>

<p>Specifications and DocumentationCurious about how Longhouse was built?  Take a look through our documentation listed below. </p>

<p> Table of Contents </p>

<p>Requirements Document Project Plan Test Plan Test Results Design Document UI Design Document Usability Analysis Usability Testing Plan</p>

 title : The macdadi Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>MACDADI has gone live! Try our prototype MACDADI server. </p>

<p>AEC professionals need to define goals, propose options, analyze these options with respect to the goals, and make decisions. Design is a social and technical process; they need to coordinate these processes and information amongst a wide range of team members and stakeholders. MACDADI (which stand for Multi-Attribute, Collaborative Design, Assessment, and Decision Integration) is designed to help establish teams, collect and hierarchically organize project goals; establish priorities; analyze design options with respect to the goals; and assist in a transparent and formal trade-off and decision making process. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>The following academic conference paper describes some of the theory and applications of MACDADI:  </p>

<p>Haymaker, J. and Chachere, J. (2006). “Coordinating Goals, Preferences, Options, and Analyses for the Stanford Living Laboratory Feasibility Study,” Intelligent Computing in Engineering and Architecture 13th EG-ICE Revised Selected Papers, Lecture Notes in Computer Science, Vol. 4200/2006, Ian Smith (ed.), Springer-Verlag, Berlin, Heidelberg, New York, pp. 320-327. </p>

<p>Haymaker, J., Chachere, J., and Senescu, R. (2008). [http://cife.stanford.edu/online.publications/TR178.pdf “Measuring and Improving Rationale Clarity in a University Office Building Design Process”&quot; CIFE Technical report # 178 </p>

<p>Chachere, J., and Haymaker, J. (2008). “Framework for Measuring Rationale Clarity of AEC Design Decisions,” CIFE Technical Report # 177</p>

 title : The magento-cn Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Magento简体中文翻译项目Magento简体中文翻译项目旨在为Magento简体中文翻译人员提供一个协同工作的平台。 </p>

<p>要参与本项目，您需要有一个Google帐号，如果您已经注册了Google帐号，请使用该帐号登录并发送注册请求给项目管理员。 </p>

<p>了解Magento翻译Magento支持两种翻译模式，inline translation和string lists, 本项目采用第二种方式。 </p>

<p>Inline translation: 本方法允许翻译者直接在Magento页面上直接对相应词条做翻译，翻译结果将存入Magento数据库。 Strings list: 按模块翻译，每个模块有一个csv文件，无须访问Magento页面，本项目采用此种方式，翻译结果请直接提交到svn。 </p>

<p>更多信息请参考： </p>

<p>Magento Community Translation Tool Magento in Multiple Languages - Translations Getting Started Magento Community Translations Useful Tools to work on Translations </p>

<p>关于SVN本项目使用svn进行协同工作，有关于svn访问信息，请 点击这里，如果您不熟悉svn，请参考 SubTrain – Open Source Trainings for Subversion 或者通过搜索引擎查找其他svn使用相关信息。 </p>

<p>Magento 最新中文翻译使用本地址 </p>

<p>svn co --user-name yourname https://magento-cn.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/(For English version of this page, please click here.)</p>
 title : The mas-uml-modeler Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The University of Calgary: Schulich School of EngineeringENEL  583/589: Fourth Year Software Engineering Team Design Project  
<br/>Team Number:5 </p>

<p>Project Title:Design and Implementation of a Software Application for Modeling Multiagent Systems Inter Behaviour Using UML 2.0 </p>

<p>Faculty Advisor:Dr.Far </p>

<p>Team:Brooks Riley </p>

<p>===== Biography ===== Brooks Riley is a 4th Year Software Engineering Student at the University of Calgary. He is currently an employee of the University of Calgary Information Technologies department. His areas of academic interest are Object Orientated Design, Agile methodologies and Large-Scale systems. </p>

<p>Lucian Aron===== Biography ===== Lucian Aron is a 4th Year Software Engineering Student studying at the Schulich School of Engineering at the University of Calgary and expecting to graduate in the spring of 2008. Lucian has completed a one year internship term with Shaw Cablesystems where he was responsible for testing and supporting Digital Satellite Systems belonging to Starchoice.  </p>

<p>Tatyana Rabinovitch </p>

<p>===== Biography ===== Tatyana Rabinovitch is in her fourth year at the Schulich School of Engineering at the University of Calgary. She speaks fluently in both Russian and English. She also worked as a summer student in the Engineering Department, holding a position as a System&#39;s Analyst.  </p>

<p>Haysam Alsayed </p>

<p>===== Biography ===== Haysam Alsayed is a fourth year software engineering student studying at the Schulich School of Engineering at the University of Calgary expecting to graduate in the spring of 2008.  Haysam was away on internship for a duration of 16 months working in Markham, Ontario for IBM Software Lab as part of the DB2 System Verification Test team.  </p>

<p>Project Description:Agent is a software entity which has the capability of performing autonomous actions on behalf of its user or owner. A Multiagent System (MAS) is a software system which consists of a number of agents that interact with each other using an Agent Communication Language or Protocol. Autonomous behavior of a software agent makes analysis of the MAS behavior hard and complicated. UML models, such as interaction and collaboration diagrams can examine the internal behavior of the MAS accurately and effectively, because they can depict the communication among agents and possible emergent behavior or deadlocks with appropriate details.   In this project we will design and implement a software application that accepts at its input the specification of an existing multiagent system and produces a suitable behavioral model compliant with UML 2.0 as its output. The reason of using UML 2.0 is its expressive potential and its wide acceptance. </p>

<p>Steps and objectives which are defined for this project:1-Choosing the most suitable MAS development specification methodology. </p>

<p>2-Designing a multiagent system using the development methodology’s constructs and models. </p>

<p>3-Design and implementation of an application that converts the developed multiagent system’s model to a compliant UML 2.0 behavioural model.  </p>

<p>4-Verification and validation of the application. </p>

<p>Required skills/knowledge:1-Being familiar with agent based software engineering and multiagent system. ( Training session will be provided)  </p>

<p>2-Good knowledge of UML diagrams and their usage in software modeling. </p>

<p>3-Good knowledge of programming with one of the programming languages like C++, C# or Java.   </p>

<p>Remark:The development process will be guided and monitored by a MSc. student who has the role of the customer’s representative in the development team to help the developers in clarifying the concepts and help them to gain background knowledge which is necessary for this project. </p>

<p>List of Expected Deliverables:ENEL 583Two major reports for the ENEL 583 semester are:Project Report #1: Mission Statement and Product Specifications. Due Nov 9th, 2007  </p>

<p>Project Report #2: High Level Design and Project Schedule. Due Dec 14th, 2007 </p>

<p>Four major assignments for the ENEL 583 semester are:Assignment #1: Prepare a &quot;Mission Statement.&quot; Due Oct 5th, 2007 </p>

<p>Assignment #2: Prepare a set of &quot;Product Specifications.&quot; Due Oct 19th, 2007 </p>

<p>Assignment #3: Prepare a &quot;High-Level Design.&quot; Due Nov 14th, 2007 </p>

<p>Assignment #4: Prepare a &quot;Project Schedule.&quot; Due Nov 14th, 2007 </p>

<p>Group Presentation for the ENEL 583 semesterNovember 27, 2007 10:30am - 11:00am ENA 227 </p>

<p>ENEL 589Two major reports for the ENEL 589 semester are:Project Report #1: Acceptance Test Plan and Detailed Design. Due March 7th, 2008  </p>

<p>Project Report #2: Test Report and Project Documentation. Due April 18th, 2008 </p>

<p>Four major assignments for the ENEL 589 semester are:Assignment #1: Prepare a &quot;Acceptance Test Plan.&quot; Due Feb 8th, 2008 </p>

<p>Assignment #2: Prepare a &quot;Detailed Design.&quot; Due Feb 29th, 2008 </p>

<p>Assignment #3: Prepare a &quot;Test Report.&quot; Due March 21st, 2008 </p>

<p>Assignment #4: Prepare &quot;Project Documentation.&quot; Due April 4th, 2008 </p>

<p>Group Presentation for the ENEL 589 semesterApril 8, 2008 10:00am - 10:30am ENA 227 </p>

 title : The milkblackmath Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Milk: Make include list kit - Black Math edition </p>

<p>Reusing JSDB (from Shanti Rao), which is basically a host embdedding SpiderMonkey, Milk provide some common build tasks for your ECMAScript projects in a command-line tool. </p>

<p>Wait... </p>

<p>First, JSDB realy is a great tool, and even if you can compile it in such a way that you can obtain an executable for Windows and Linux, you can obtain only a command-line tool, and Milk just crave for a GUI. </p>

<p>Second, Milk in JSDB is already done, but honestly the code just sucks and I&#39;m ashamed of it, and worst the tool smells the unmaintainable big ball of mud coded in 2 days smells. </p>

<p>So, Milk will be based on Apollo and be redone from scratch and hopefully have an improved design. </p>

<p>My goal for Milk is to make a swiss army knife for building any ECMASCript source code. </p>

<p>Another goal (and not a secondary one) is to provide a &#39;GUI in context&#39;, that means depending on the context of your task compiling Flex2 / compacting JavaScript / etc. the visuals and options of Milk change dynamically. </p>

<p>Priority One Features planed: </p>

<p>one executable/host, no dependencies, cross-platform Win/Mac (Linux if possible) a comprehensive GUI but still powerfull command-line arguments combine multi files to one file remove comments from source code compact source code General Features planed: </p>

<p>GUI panel to compile with Flex 2 compiler GUI panel to compile Apollo applications ECMAScript config files save/load config files different profile (dev, release, debug, etc.) zip files/releases upload files/zip to FTP generate a detailled log of the building run unit tests generate unit tests generate ReadMe, etc. from template get info from Subversion This project will start as soon a public alpha/beta for Apollo will appear AND will support exe access.</p>
 summary : <p>MindWeb+IntroductionFreeMind and MindWeb are both open source projects which are hosted in sourceforge.net.  FreeMind is a excellent tool to create MindMap on PC.  title : The mindwebplus Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>minivecA pure python 2D vector class for general use. There are several reasons why a developer would choose this class over other choices. </p>

<p>Flexible ArgumentsAny method or operator requiring a vector should accept as many types of objects as possible. This includes single number values, any object that is a pair of numbers, or any object with a vec2 attribute that is a pair of numbers. </p>

<p>Floating PointAll values and math should be done with floating point values. Any arguments passed as integers will be coerced as necessary. </p>

<p>Immutable methodsAll methods and operators return new vectors, and each one is immutable. </p>

<p>Error resistantThere will be no errors with zero length normals. Some operations may not be defined, but DivideByZero exception will never be raised. </p>

<p>FastVector operations should be as fast as possible. But speed should not interfere with any of the above features. It turns out that this vector class is one of the fastest available. Out performing other pure python implementations that offer a less convenient interface. </p>

<p>Hello, VectorA simple &quot;Hello, World&quot; for the vector class, creating many vectors that have the same value. </p>

<p>a = Vec2(12)
<br/>b = Vec2(12.0, 12.0)
<br/>c = Vec2([12, 12])
<br/>d = Vec(12) - Vec(0)
<br/>e = Vec(6) * 2
<br/>f = Vec(6, 12) * (2, 1)
<br/>g = Vec(24) / 2</p>
 title : The minivec Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>What is it?Minjava is a Java reverse engineering software. It means that it can help to understand the architecture and behavior of an existing Java software. </p>

<p>How does that works?Minjava is based on a Java meta-model, that defines how the possible Java softwares can be structured. An importer analyzes a Java source code or byte-code to build a Java model. This Java model is then used by different reverse engineering tools, like a class diagram generator. For more information on the design of Minjava, visit the MinjavaDesign page. </p>

<p>How can I get it ?See the MinjavaInstall page. </p>

<p>What can it do for me?Java developersAutomatic drawing of class diagrams Automatic drawing of packages dependencies diagram Metrics computation and report in HTML Reverse engineering tool designersFurnish a Java meta-model that can be used as a basis in the building of numerous reverse engineering tools DocumentationSee the MinjavaDocumentation page. </p>

<p>ScreenshotsSee the MinjavaScreenshots page. </p>

<p>DevelopmentSee the MinjavaDev page. </p>

<p>LicenseMinjava is released under the terms of the Eclipse Public License v2.0r </p>

<p>AuthorsThe authors of Minjava are from the LIRMM institute. </p>

<p>Jean-Rémy Falleri : Minjava project leader.</p>

 title : The mythos Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Mythos is a GUI library written in C++ using modern C++ techniques.  While it is functional, it is for the most part a proof of concept for several ideas I had w/ regard to GUI libraries.  Mythos is divided into four sub-libraries: </p>

<p>khaos - khaos handles platform/window system abstraction.  It provides a simple, generic API to create/manipulate windows, create/use fonts, and define a program&#39;s entry point.  It also contains some font rendering code, though this should really be part of an extension to Boost.GIL (Adobe&#39;s Generic Image Library).  Currently the only working backend to khaos is the x11 backend.  There is also a backend that uses wxWidgets, but it is broken (see wxWidgetsBackend for more info). annex - annex is a small library packaged with khaos that deals with plugins.  It is used by gaia. nyx - nyx is a window layout library.  It contains a DSEL (Domain Specific Embedded Language) that allows users to specify a window&#39;s layout without having to resort to specific values or layout classes (as done in gtk).  The resulting code will also give an idea as to what the layout will look like:     layout(my_window, padx, pady) =
<br/>        rows[ &quot;Hello world!&quot;            ]
<br/>            [ button1 | right[button2]  ]
<br/>        ;iris - iris is the event handling part of Mythos.  It allows users to associate actions (functions or functors) with events through the use of another DSEL, then attach the created event handlers to windows:     // from the custom gaia implementation example
<br/>    namespace on = mythos::iris::on;</p>

<p>    checkbox_state_type state;</p>

<p>    iris::event_handler evts =
<br/>        // state is copied and stored in the event_handler.  it is passed to the following actions, when the event occurs.
<br/>        iris::context(state)
<br/>        [
<br/>            (on::l_button_down | on::l_button_up)   [change_checkbox_state], // change_checkbox_state is a function
<br/>            on::paint                               [checkbox_paint]         // ditto
<br/>        ]
<br/>        ;</p>

<p>    // add evts to my_window&#39;s intrusive list of event_handlers using the connect function, which was shamelessly stolen
<br/>    // from wxWidgets
<br/>    my_window.connect(evts);</p>

<p>    // each nyx::window also contains a event_handler whose lifetime the window manages.  this way a window can hold and
<br/>    // manage state if it needs to, while still keeping the details transparent with regard to the user.
<br/>    my_window.events() = evts;gaia - gaia handles widget toolkit abstraction.  It consists primarily of free functions that take data and create widgets (which are returned as nyx::windows).  Data is passed to these functions mostly by reference.  This way, users can manipulate widgets, without needing small, separate APIs for each widget.  For example, to create a checkbox, then change whether the checkbox is checked, one would need to do the following:     bool value = true;</p>

<p>    // value is held by reference
<br/>    nyx::window cb = gaia::checkbox(value);</p>

<p>    // ... layout/show toplevel window ...</p>

<p>    // uncheck the checkbox
<br/>    value = false;
<br/>    iris::paint(cb);While this does help to simplify things (no special checkbox class, no need to intrusively find and modify data held by the window), it requires the user to manage data.   
<br/>gaia is also pluggable.  This means users can, theoretically, switch between different toolkits at runtime.  To load gaia, an init function must be called (gaia::init(...)).  There are two init functions, one loads a specific gaia implementation, and the other finds and loads a default one.  Unfortunately, the latter has not been implemented. 
<br/>Currently there are no implementations of gaia (save a sample one, and one based on wxWidgets, which cannot be used). 
<br/>To build Mythos with bjam, run bjam with --platform=x11 or whatever the target platform is meant to be.  The environment variable BOOST_ROOT must be set. </p>

<p>Mythos uses the following libraries: </p>

<p>GIL 2.1  Boost (SVN) Boost.Switch fontconfig freetype Xlib </p>

<p>Mythos has been tested on gcc 4.1.2 under Ubuntu.</p>
 title : The namatjira Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A Flash exploration game., </p>

<p>If you are interested in contributing to the NanoBot project, please contact Daedius Moskvitch (daedius@daedius.com) </p>

<p>FeaturesCrossplatform Notification via email,irc,web Master-Slave architecture Nant support NUnit support Support for grid testing Comparison To Other Automated Build/Testing MethodsCruiseControl.NetSupporting the master slave architecture will be vastly different from CC&#39;s centralized approach, but it will allow us more flexability and decentralization of tests on many platforms. It will also enable us to run certain tests which require multiple computers for grid testing. This project has a great system of xml specification for projects and support for Nant,Nunit,NCop, etc we could learn from. CruiseControlOnce again, our project will have a focus on distributed testing and building. Our support for C# technologies will be within our control if something goes wrong.  Also, knowing how mono works on all platforms is much easier than knowing how both Java and Mono work on all platforms. BuildBotBuildbot has a great architecture for distributed builds and testing which we will be using extensively as a general direction We will not use Python as a configuration language, rather we will be using XML structures more similar in CruiseControl We will have more direct support for C# technologies Manual Building &amp; TestingMore efficient More automated More proven</p>

 title : The neverlost Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The nibz Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Donate via Payal </p>

<p>NIBZ is a compact innovative microprocessor described in VHDL. The innovation is based around how the machine encodes instructions. There are 16 basic instructions and one advanced call instruction. The advanced call instruction gives the density of direct threaded code with the speed of subroutine threaded code. Certain choices of instruction were purposefully left out. A good example being a literal value load. When threaded code is analyzed, it can be seen that this instruction would not be used very often, as the placement of that value onto a stack makes for extra instructions, loosing code density. </p>

<p>There is an (A)ccumulator and 4 main registers </p>

<p>(P)rogram Counter (the code flow) (Q)uality Register (adds some quality and memory indexing ability easy) (R)eturn Stack Pointer (the threading and route to literal fetching and branching) (S)tack Pointer (for ALU and data operation) This processor is dedicated to the Moores and the more&#39;s and the moors. </p>

<p>The 16 basic instructions are encoded in the low nibble of a machine code word. The advanced call instruction is identified by being greater than 15. This has many benefits, including elimination of some branch delay slots in a full pipeline architecture, and effective little-endian load pre-decoding. It must be noted that the memory organization is big endian, even though fetches and stores are done in little endian order. </p>

<p>From NibzX onwards a 3 in 1 opcode compression feature has been added. This uses the lower 16K words to present virtual subroutines of 3 instructions. This is the video area too on the ReferenceSystem and so has no conflict. </p>

<p>The first project phase is complete with a half width data bus for using cheaper memory. This places total instruction fetch and execution time to 5 cycles. The second project phase concentrating on the IO is now in progress. </p>

<p>Phase 1 : Processor Phase 2 : An IO standard (Graphics, Sound, SPI Boot, SD Card, 2*8 Bit Ports) Phase 3 : A Hardware Reference Phase 4 : An Emulator Phase 5 : Multi-processing To Clarify Licence IssuesA one core (single instruction stream execution) per chip (piece of silicon/SOI/GaAs cut to fit a mounting) licence is available for free. This allows use in propritory designs, while still allowing full utility (any number of cores) in open BSD designs. The instruction design is well suited to dataflow multiple dispatch, with the elimination of cycle overheads of stack shuffling.  </p>

<p>Have a look at the InstructionSet for more details. The VHDL is OpenSource BSD and the VHDL was produced with the aid of Altera Quartus II. This project will be given a boost by the development of a Forth language system for it. The this is started on Gforth for nibz . A J2MERef java source of the instuction operation is available, to be used in an emulator, although it is quite old and has not been modified to the new instruction timings. </p>

<p>A hardware ReferenceSystem is in the design process. </p>

<p>This is an n+4 design all extension is via n+5, etc..  For an insight on how generalization to programming of Objects will occur, Think Object Transfer Language, although this is a long way off. </p>

<p>Check VersionList for version details and extras. Try WhatIsVHDL too, to see an old version. </p>

<p>The OldDesign indi proessor is now not developed, but the design can be downloaded. The reason for the change is obvious when threaded code is considered. </p>

<p>K Ring Technologies Semiconductor </p>

<p>The Direct Injection Switching Channel Organization (DISCO) FET symbol above is based upon the idea of a parallel channel which charges, but does not conduct, either by doping levels or a thicker oxide layer. The resulting antiphase injection or collection of charge carriers reduces the miller capacitance effect. </p>

<p>&quot;Yet more great technology from K Ring.&quot; - Simon Jackson, BEng. </p>

<p>Charitable Director and Creative Technologist </p>

<p>Phone/Fax/Forwarding: +44 (0)709 289 7191 (yac.com) Phone SMS Only: +44 (0)796 797 3001 (Orange) Phone: +44 (0)1924 635 485 (Tesco Internet Phone)</p>

 summary : <p>Prototype., </p>
 title : The nuclear-project Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Project NuclearProject Nuclear seeks to create a set of high quality samplers, synthesizers and effects on the GNU/Linux platform and facilitate tools for their development. To do so we maintain our own developer friendly SDK to make the job fun again. </p>

<p>The Nuclear SDK will be in the form of header-only libraries, similar to Boost, with no need for their own compilation. Just include them in your code and take advantage of the functions they offer. </p>

<p>Project Nuclear always welcome new DSP wizards, graphic designer elves and developer orchs to join our cause and start develop synthesizers and effects as part of the project. But you are just as welcome if all you want is to deploy our SDK in your own project. </p>

<p>Google Code host our developer documentation wiki, subversion repository and issue tracker while our main site contains information about our community and plugins. </p>

<p>Why “Nuclear?”At first, the name was meant to be poking fun at Native Instrument’s Reaktor, calling it Nuklear at the time. Failing to come up with any better name, we decided to stick with Nuclear, going with the English spelling to hopefully avoid any trademark trouble. The “Project” part got tacked on because there was already a project called “Nuclear” out there on SourceForge. </p>

<p>Who is “We?”The Nuclear Project currently consists of Anders Dahnielson, of Sweden, and Darren Landrum, of the United States. </p>

<p>Contacting UsDarren Landrum can be contacted directly at dmlandrum at gmail dot com. We can also be contact through our Google Group.</p>

 title : The pedal-de-efectos Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>El proyecto consite en implementar un circuito electrónico basado en un dsPIC que permite a un usuario la generacion de distintos efectos albergado generalmente en una pequeña caja metálica, produciendo una alteracion en la calidad del sonido o timbre de la señal de entrada, añadiendo distintos efectos al sonido producido. Cuando el pedal esté apagado o inactivo, la señal pasa de manera pasiva por este, por lo que no se ve alterada, hacia los otros pedales conectados a la cadena de modo que cualquier combinación de efectos en la cadena pueda ser creada sin tener que conectar y desconectar cajas de efectos al estar en una presentación o ensayo. La señal puede ser direccionada a través de las cajas de efectos con cualquier combinación, pero lo más común es poner la señal de distorsión. Para reconocer el tipo de efecto que se tiene en el pedal se tiene un display que desplegara el efecto seleccionado por el usuario.</p>
